662598991.name: Must see this church- amazing place
662598991.author: a TripAdvisor user
662598991.reviewBody: I am so glad I had the opportunity to visit chill and see this extraordinary church. It  cannot be missed. So different than anything I have see in any church in Mexico. My guide as thorough in his presentation of the church, its art and the edifice so magnificently constructed.

646147482.name: Architecture, History, Religion, Chaos and Death
646147482.author: a TripAdvisor user
646147482.reviewBody: The tiles in the facade are beautifully chaotic, this is one of the most beautiful facades you will see anywhere.   You will find history, architecture, religion, chaos and death all within the same church.  Literally thousands of tiles on the facade, a beautiful garden and a small cemetery with beautiful messages from their grieving relatives.\n\nIt worth the visit!

645817618.name: a nice stop on a tour bus from cholula zocalo 90 pesos less than 2 hr tour
645817618.author: a TripAdvisor user
645817618.reviewBody: the front of the church has a lot of details and it is nice inside as well. the front had some damage from the earthquake in the fall of 17 so we entereded from a side entrance.

644840840.name: Fantastic Talavera tiled church in Cholula
644840840.author: a TripAdvisor user
644840840.reviewBody: Perhaps the prettiest church in Mexico.  It took 100 years to complete and no wonder, the whole outside fascade of the church in decorated with blue Talavera tiles.  Inside, the tiles are blue, white, yellow and green.  Lots of statues to. Sort of medium indigenous baroque.  Lots of gold.

636762535.name: Fantastic Primative Baroque
636762535.author: a TripAdvisor user
636762535.reviewBody: This interior is overwhelming to the eyes, and so charming as it is a bit less refined than the churches in Puebla.

619596288.name: Very Beautiful
619596288.author: a TripAdvisor user
619596288.reviewBody: This is one of the most interesting and beautiful churches that I have seen. The outside is coved in tile, which is a product of Puebla. The inside is richly decorated. Worth a visit.

603096387.name: A tripple wow! Don\u2019t skip it!
603096387.author: a TripAdvisor user
603096387.reviewBody: Facade is just breath-taking. If you just see the outside you are more than served. Watch every corner of the talavera tiles decorating the towers, and inside is also very different as natives had the freedom to decorate it with a local touch. Need to see it! It is a piece of joy.

600034989.name: Beautiful yellow exterior
600034989.author: a TripAdvisor user

5* p San Francisco de Atacayo

591298757.name: Great tile
591298757.author: a TripAdvisor user
591298757.reviewBody: The Talvera tile on the exterior of this church is considered one of the great architectural details in Mexico. The interior had great detail. A must see. Combine it with your visit to the Cholula pyramid. 60 peso Uber ride between the two.

571739074.name: Very cool church
571739074.author: a TripAdvisor user
571739074.reviewBody: Excellent tiles on the outside, very nice on the inside. The main entrance is closed due to reconstruction for the earthquake, but you can get in the side near the cloisters. Well worth the side trip if you are visiting the pyramid.

674600043.name: Was it necessary?
674600043.author: a TripAdvisor user
674600043.reviewBody: With all due respect to History and Christian faith, was it necessary to build up a church like other thousands on top of such a majestic structure? And I say so, knowing that the authors of such a deed were Spaniards like myself

671318862.name: The view is worth ever step
671318862.author: a TripAdvisor user
671318862.reviewBody: We went on a day that the clouds were out and the volcanic was hard to see. But the views of the city were increadable. There was a  celebration happening the day we went so we help people carry huge amounts of food up to the church. The church is beautiful like most churches we have seen in Mexico. 667437814.name: Exquisite church
667437814.author: a TripAdvisor user
667437814.reviewBody: The church of Iglesia de Nuestra Senora de Los Remedios is located 100 kilometres from Mexico City in Cholula. The church is famous for being built in 1575 on top of the largest pyramid known in the world - they did not know the Pyramid was there at the time! \nFrom a distance it all looks like a church on a hill  - but the beautiful church is built on the Great Pyramid of Cholula. It is free to enter the church but you pay 75 pesos to enter the archeological tunnels that run through the pyramid. Once you exit the tunnel you view the excavation of the pyramid. \nThe church though is very beautiful and offers amazing views over Cholula. Well worth a visit.

itemReviewed.name: Iglesia de Nuestra Senora de los Remedios

666198591.name: Don\'t Be Taking Any Photos
666198591.author: a TripAdvisor user
666198591.reviewBody: Photography of the inside is strictly forbidden.  Surprising since these folks built their church on top of another civilizations religious temple.  Talk about hypocrisy.

665557199.reviewBody: It is beautiful Like all the town of San Pedro Cholula, very old. Its square is beautiful and its church zone also. To get to this church you must go up a few steps but nothing too complicated considering that you are on a walk. 658905394.name: Get here by 7am to get any views
658905394.author: a TripAdvisor user
658905394.reviewBody:
Too much pollution... we got here by 9am and did not see the Popocatepetl except for some silhouettes through the fog.

Thankfully, the pyramid was too big and covered in dust for the Spanish to destroy it so they did the next best they could do - destroyed a few protruding temples and built this on top of the pyramid.  

You can get to the top but this a climb alright.

itemReviewed.name: Iglesia de Nuestra Senora de los Remedios

651882454.name: Stunning views
651882454.author: a TripAdvisor user
651882454.reviewBody: This is a very beautiful church, a peaceful place for prayer and meditation. Of great historical interest, its construction began in the late 1500\'s atop the Great Pyramid, with several restorations after earthquake damage. Visitors may walk in the sacristy to see earlier sculptures of Our Lady of Remedies, ceiling murals of Spanish colonial activity, and educational panels in Spanish.  No photography is allowed in the church, so you will have to visit to see its beauty.  And then there\'s the view from the plaza around the Church!!!  Stunning views of volcanoes Popocatepetl, Ixtaccihuatl, and Malinche.  We observed steam venting from the caldera of active volcano Popocatepetl, and lingered on the plaza on two separate evenings to appreciate the gorgeous sunset. Worth bringing warm layers in the winter, as there can be a cool breeze after the sun goes down.  Accessible by taxi, Uber, or by tourist train from Puebla. We stayed in Cholula, so it was a short walk. The path to the Church is paved, a mix of gentle slopes and stairs.

644841266.author: a TripAdvisor user

There are steps to get up to the church but we found a ramp which seemed to be easier.  On the way down we found an easier way, that entrance is street side.  The views are spectacular, and the church is stunning.  Pics of the inside of the church can only be taken while standing in the entrance.

620550359.name: A must in Cholula
620550359.author: a TripAdvisor user
620550359.reviewBody: The museum offers different exhibitions showcasing the art, history, and culture of the region with the help of animations and a 360 degree movie.

478208072.name: A must
478208072.author: a TripAdvisor user
478208072.reviewBody: Amazing museum. I didn\'t expect such a complete and well maintained museum in Cholula. The collection is interesting and informative. You don\'t need to spend a lot of time but definitely worth it.

472976270.name: This is actually Museo Regional Cholula
472976270.author: a TripAdvisor user
472976270.reviewBody: Just opened in January 2017, the Cholula Regional Museum should be at the top of your sightseeing list.  Excellent Pre-Colombian collection, Mexican folk art, sacred art, all housed on beautiful, expansive grounds.  Well worth several hours, especially if you lunch at their on site restaurant.  Wheelchair accessible.

460403879.name: Brilliant collection and exquisite repurposing
460403879.author: a TripAdvisor user
460403879.reviewBody: This museum is next to the Ruins and offers multimedia presentations on the geology of the Puebla-Tlaxcala Valley.  The history of the area and its Maya Toltec Aztec and post colonial times is exhibited in the several hospital white out buildings that made up the asylum. New architecture graces the site with more display, meeting and eating spaces.

459250880.name: From psychiatric hospital to museum
459250880.author: a TripAdvisor user
459250880.reviewBody:
The place was a psychiatric hospital during the XX century but now it was rebuild to host the Museo de Sitio de Cholula.

The new building preserve the architecture of the original place, but holds a totally new interiors that mix legends, history, a collection of pieces found in Cholula, and digital experiences.

The building is beautiful and it is a very nice experience to walk from building to building, among the gardens.

The restoration was excellent so it is possible to have a very good idea about the place during the psychiatric days. It is been said the Liz Taylor and Freddie Mercury was internals once here. But the place looks very nice and during the night, is you walk in Cholula, the illumination adds to the church on top of the pyramid and the view is superb.

It takes about two hours to visit the museum, and I suggest to do it first, before enter the tunnels of the pryramid, since the exit of the tunnels end at the other side of the pyramid.

613967336.name: Nice place to have a stroll
613967336.author: a TripAdvisor user
613967336.reviewBody: This is a nice place to have a stroll, there are plenty of restaurants and shops around this square.

478210810.name: Nice place to walk
478210810.author: a TripAdvisor user
478210810.reviewBody: This central square is full with town life. A market fills the plaza and it is surrounded by a couple of churches and many local restaurants.

467043496.name: Relaxing place in the center of a quiet city
467043496.author: a TripAdvisor user
467043496.reviewBody:
When we talked about this city to people we met, looked at artesanias here in the main plaza, and read my Lonely Planet guidebook, all called it simply Cholula. But most of the TripAdvisor listings are under its formal name, San Pedro Cholula. Whatever... FYI.

It's a tree-shaded plaza with lots of benches (we always seemed to find some). There's a gazebo toward the west side. All four days we were in Cholula, there were vendors selling artesanias. For food. there were frozen treats and elote (boiled corn served on a stick, with mayonnaise and polvo (hot chile powder). There's much more food at restaurants that line the west-side portal and at restaurants like Guero's and the authentic Mexican :) Subway. 

There are churches, too (San Pedro Apostol on the north side and Convento de San Gabriel on the east). Google Maps says that next to San Pedro Apostol is the Museo de Ciudad de Cholula -- which we didn't manage to visit.

Cholula is a great alternative to Puebla for staying the night. It's much quieter, and it's only a 10 km bus ride away. (There's also a train from near the Gran Pyramide. We didn't try it because it's a fair distance from the plaza.) A hotel on the plaza, like Hotel MS, make this area a really good choice.

636762442.author: a TripAdvisor user
636762442.reviewBody: This is the main church on the plaza in Cholula and has a pretty cloister and interior.  The smaller chapel has a more ornate altar.

624314779.name: A must visit if you are in Cholula
624314779.author: a TripAdvisor user
624314779.reviewBody: An easy walk from the pyramid area. Off the main square. Not sure why it is named here as \u201cex\u201d convent as it is an active Franciscan friary with about 10 friars working there. There is a large school, the Franciscan Library, a huge chapel that at one time was open air to allow for thousands to be present for Mass, and the actual church and friary itself, is one of the oldest in the Americas. The actual original cloister is not accesible because of some damage to the original bell tower from an earthquake so the church entrance is closed off, but you can still access the church on the side. If you run into one of the friars, they can get you into the original cloister area which not too many people get to see. As someone else mentioned, the entire complex is huge, so you almost have to make a decision whether to soak everything in from the courtyard or to go inside and visit.

603098434.name: Magestic convent with colorful history
603098434.author: a TripAdvisor user
603098434.reviewBody: It is one of those places where you must take the decision whether you look the inside or just relax in the shades of the trees outside. Wonderful place.

570182517.name: Beautiful In Every Way
570182517.author: a TripAdvisor user
570182517.reviewBody: The striking yellow and rock exterior combined with a relatively modern interior with Cordoba-like arches and seemingly open spaces made this a visual pleasure.

566849817.name: Beautiful Church
566849817.author: a TripAdvisor user
566849817.reviewBody: This is a beatutiful church which was unfortunately hardly hit by the earthquakes (leave a small donation for rebuilding the convent). It is still worth visiting it - come in the morning because some parts of the area are closed in the afternoon.

562529961.name: We visited this quaint old church, lots of history and a volcano
562529961.author: a TripAdvisor user
562529961.reviewBody: We visited this church right after we had seen the Cholula Pyramid, our guide mentioned how this church had been built with stones from the pyramid and that this church had been damaged by a recent earthquake, we went inside and heard more of its history. When we came out we had wait a few minutes for our tour bus, that\'s when Popo the neighborhood volcano got our attention, the guide said don\'t worry, that happens all the time, ok

478209579.name: Huge
478209579.author: a TripAdvisor user
478209579.reviewBody: This place is really huge. The central patio is really big for the size of the city. The church is not one of the most beautiful but it in the middle of town so worth a visit.

459747495.name: Lovely exhibition too
459747495.author: a TripAdvisor user
459747495.reviewBody: Well kept up.  I didn\'t have a lot of time to tour this but loved the things I saw.   The exhibition was great - music, art and architecture.    It surprised me that each place we visited was different than the other.   They do start running together in my mind but having the photos helps.  And posting here.    I suggest you make a list of each place you visit and a few things you liked about it.  Otherwise you won\'t remember.

457005755.name: Impressive church, chapel and courtyard
457005755.author: a TripAdvisor user
457005755.reviewBody: Located next to the main plaza of Cholula, this church, chapel and courtyard are impressive examples of the religious architecture and life of the colonial era.  The chapel next to the main church has several interior arches and domes in the Moorish style of Andalucia.  The courtyard outside the church and chapel has been maintained and the entire complex is still surrounded by external walls. These features are unusual in Mexico, where so much church property was expropriated in the 19th century.

443196387.name: Beautiful and interesting
443196387.author: a TripAdvisor user
443196387.reviewBody: I visited on a major religious day and there were services taking place in both churches. Outside in the courtyard, the loudest firecrackers I had ever heard were being set off. It was quite impressive. I was able to go into each church and enjoyed spending time in the courtyard. This convent, the zocalo and park were very peaceful in spite of the earsplitting celebration and a nice contrast to the three previous days I had spent in Puebla. I plan to return and look forward to the laid back, calm environs.

435181927.name: What a place!
435181927.author: a TripAdvisor user
435181927.reviewBody: Wandering the grounds it was easy to imagine the place centuries ago.  Such an amazing structure and beautiful chapel - an engineering feat to build all 39 of those domes.  Take a bit of time and just sit and relax, soak it all up.

366903060.name: Unique and Amazing Architecture
366903060.author: a TripAdvisor user
366903060.reviewBody: Though the interior of the church has been ruined by the unkind intervention of well-meaning parish priests over the years, some traces of the exquisite indigenous stone work remain. The real highlight, however, is the "Capilla de Naturales" with it\'s 49 domes. The simple, elegant design of the space has strong mystical overtones. The library in the actual former monastery is fascinating as well.

343188710.name: One of the Oldest Convents of Mexico
343188710.author: a TripAdvisor user
343188710.reviewBody: This Franciscan Convent was founded in 1529 and finished in 1552. The compound has two churches and the convent, which is still inhabited by Friars. The Capilla de Naturales is extremely interesting, as it resembles to the Mezquita de Cordoba in Spain. The Cloister is very elegant and has beautiful frescoes from the XVI Century.

340582961.name: Church or convent?
340582961.author: a TripAdvisor user
340582961.reviewBody: Declared as convent, but in fact you visit two churches. If you are in Cholula, it is worth visiting it, but doesn\'t justify special visit

338322202.name: A truly beautiful place
338322202.author: a TripAdvisor user
338322202.reviewBody: The convent of San Gabriel is a large building with four brightly painted yellow sides enclosing a quadrangle. One of the sides then becomes another side to Cholula\'s Zocalo, the main square of the town and, after New Mexico, the second largest Zocalo in Mexico. The Zocalo is also painted in the same bright yellow colours. Whilst we were there, a group of Mexican Indians were setting up to do their version of what British Morris dancers do, only at the top of huge pole in the middle of the Zocalo. The entire trip to Cholula was a joy.

647597351.name: OPENED IN NOVEMBER 2018
647597351.author: a TripAdvisor user
647597351.reviewBody: It is not the typical shopping center, as it has many options for fun and entertainment like mechanical games for families,  an area for youngsters like climbing walls, many games for children, an ice rink, cinemas, etc.  There is also an area of small restaurants, each set inside metal containers, like those carried by cargo ships.  An area of larger restaurants too, around a nice green area.  A foodcourt area too and two large corridors with clothing and shoes stores.  A nice visit, I liked it a lot!

372881490.name: No tours. Weak ciders.
372881490.author: a TripAdvisor user
372881490.reviewBody: Came on advice of Trip Advisor. Having a sip of the ciders in this mausoleum. Heck, the sell coffins next door too. Was surprised that it\'s just a shop with a video (that\'s broken right now)

139374902.name: Enjoy wonderful cider and a great tour
139374902.author: a TripAdvisor user
139374902.reviewBody: This is a famous cider mill in the heart of San Pedro Cholula.  This company has been in business for 75 years and produces high quality bottled cider.  They provide tours of 10 people or more and it consists of an orientation on the manufacture of cider, a visit to the pressing and fermenting rooms.  The tour ends at the orientation room where guests are given cider samples.  They also make a few canned items, such as apple sauce, of which samples are also provided.  The main entrance has a museum and store where you can purchase their products.  Oh, and did I mention the tour is free?

666950284.name: Great place!
666950284.author: a TripAdvisor user
666950284.reviewBody: Authentic market with great local food, interesting produce and herbs. Great way to meet some of the locals.

609973930.name: Great Market to explore
609973930.author: a TripAdvisor user
609973930.reviewBody:
This market is fantastic, you get to see some many interesting local shops with local produce, handcrafts, food, antiques, herbs, you name it.

I went around through every aisle taking pictures, buying things and talking to the sales people.

lots of fun

547658363.name: Puebla Mexico
547658363.author: a TripAdvisor user
547658363.reviewBody:
Antonio with Amigo Tours to Puebla/Cholula took us to this small market so we could shop.

We walked around the area and looked at some old architecture that was beautiful. All towns and cities should preserve these buildings!

It was a long drive from Mexico City but worth the trip!

526681135.name: Authentic Mexican Market
526681135.author: a TripAdvisor user
526681135.reviewBody: This market offers a true Mexican experience for anybody visiting Cholula. It is a great opportunity to try local food at a low price. They also sell everything beyond food, such as household accessories at a low price.

460219720.name: We came here for breakfast
460219720.author: a TripAdvisor user
460219720.reviewBody: We were visiting friends that live here in Cholula. So they brought us to this Market for breakfast. There are lots of food stands here. However, my friends chose the specific one that you can see in the pictures. We had quesadillas, which here they make with blue corn, typical in this area. Great flavor, inexpensive food, large size, wonderful popular experience.

443182461.name: Wonderful Market!
443182461.author: a TripAdvisor user
443182461.reviewBody: I love markets like this and enjoyed the opportunity to interact with locals and see a slice of daily life in Cholula. There were so many different types of fresh and dried peppers, dried beans, fruits, vegetables, colors, wonderful smells, flowers, things we don\'t see in the US and stalls where all types of food was being prepared. There was a great energy throughout the market.

428989072.name: True Local Grocery Market
428989072.author: a TripAdvisor user
428989072.reviewBody: What an experience ....a true local grocery market filled with fruits, vegetables, meat, chicken, ceramics, flowers and anything else you can imagine.   The market is a local shopping spot and a buzz of activity.  We were the only tourists strolling along the numerous indoor stalls. I loved the sights and sounds. We purchased several small ceramic "pig" bowls for salsa.  We had just eaten at Fridas and our salsa was served in these little bowls.  The restaurant owner said she buys them for the restaurant at the market.  If you want to experience local culture, the Municipal Market is worth a visit.

361774636.name: Check it out
361774636.author: a TripAdvisor user
361774636.reviewBody: If you are in the area, don\'t be afraid to stop in for a look. This is where the locals go to shop so it is nice place to experience (no pressure).

601925639.name: Muy Interesante si visitas la zona arqueol\u00f3gica de Cholula.
601925639.author: a TripAdvisor user
601925639.reviewBody: No se pueden perder el cortometraje "Cholula ciudad Sagrada", en el que puedes disfrutar de una proyecci\u00f3n animada donde se narran los misterios de \u00e9ste prehisp\u00e1nico lugar, conocer a grandes rasgos su magia, historia y grandeza. \nla funci\u00f3n dura 30 minutos y son 2 por hora desde las 10am.

627088479.author: a TripAdvisor user

672915257.name: Awesome
672915257.author: a TripAdvisor user
672915257.reviewBody: I went there knowing that this was the largest of its kind and also that a church had been built on top of it. When you arrive, soon realize that this is no Gizeh sort of pyramid, you cannot contemplate it in all its majestic size because of the ravages of time and us humans. Yet the little proportion that has been excavated by the archaeologists speaks out for the grandeur of the site. The museum, alas, does not profit (or reveal) enough of the sheer importance of the monument, in my opinion.

671903002.name: The largest pyramid on earth
671903002.author: a TripAdvisor user

You can also visit the tunnel of the pyramid,after the tunnel it\'s the archaeological sites. There is a cathedral built on the top, in a sunny day you can see Popocatepetl volcano.

671460650.author: a TripAdvisor user
671460650.reviewBody: This is one of the most important archaeological sites, not only in Mexico but the entire WORLD!\nIt is breathtaking and absolutely amazing.\nFYI. You must also visit the museum right next to the pyramid, it is excellent!

668771783.name: Wear comfy shoes
668771783.author: a TripAdvisor user
668771783.reviewBody: We explored the pyramids, walked through the museum, and walked through the tunnels. It was very interesting, albeit rather creepy, reading the stories of human sacrifice.

667436564.name: Impressive
667436564.author: a TripAdvisor user
667436564.reviewBody:
The Great Pyramid of Cholula, also known as Tlachihualtepetl, is the largest known pyramid in the world. It is located about 100 kilometres from Mexico City. Cholula is very easy to get to from Mexico City, you catch an Express bus, make sure it is the express bus, and not the slow stops every 100 metre bus, from Mexico City TAPO bus terminal. The express bus takes about 90 minutes, slow bus over 3 hours, and costs 180 pesos express, 135 slow bus. 
From the bus terminal in Cholula you have a 20-30 minute walk to the Pyramid, use Google Map. 
The pyramid costs 75 pesos to enter and you enter through the archeological tunnels dug through the pyramid. If you are very large or claustrophobic this may not be for you as it is a very tight fit and the tunnel goes for over 800 metres. 
You cannot see much of the pyramid as most is buried underground. The locals built a church on top of the pyramid in 1575 so from a distance it looks like just that ‘a hill with a church on it’!!! 
It is though fascinating, to be honest I prefer Teotihuacan pyramid complex myself, but Cholula is certainly worth the visit.

666197731.name: Ruins on the Weat and Tunnel Entrance on the East Side of Pyramid
666197731.author: a TripAdvisor user
666197731.reviewBody: The exposed ruins are on the west side ruins are on the west side of the pyramid.  Those ruins are of temples built after abandonment of the pyramid.  Entry into the the pyramid is through a tunnel on the east side.

665555569.name: Visit to Cholula
665555569.author: a TripAdvisor user
665555569.reviewBody: To one side of the pyramid there is a reconstructed monument that had been dedicated to Quetzalcoatl, next to it, there is the patio where some marble altars, monoliths and other finds of tourist interest can be seen. Both the courtyard and the tunnels inside the pyramid are open to the general public, as well as being able to ascend to the top of the pyramid. It was a great experience to be able to go through a pyramid of the colonial era and of course I recommend going to this great monument

664908758.name: Worth The Visit
664908758.author: a TripAdvisor user
664908758.reviewBody: We took a day trip from Puebla to visit the pyramid, and visit Cholula itself. We really enjoyed our time, the little museum included in the price isn\'t too bad, you will get a bit more out of it if you can read Spanish because there is more information. I wouldn\'t call myself an expert by any means, but it gave us a decent grasp of what we were seeing. Knowledge from visiting other archaeological sites in Mexico helped a lot, too. If it\'s your first time visiting this type of site in Mexico and you aren\'t familiar with it, I would suggest a guide to help you understand more.\n\nWe spent at least a couple of hours here. You only have to pay to get into the archaeological part, but there is a big park that winds around it. There were plenty of locals out for an afternoon walk because there are some nice walking paths that skirt around the site. Going inside the pyramid was pretty cool, and we spent a little while exploring what we could. Some of the buried/exposed areas of the base are really interesting to see, and there were lots of little ground squirrels running around that were amusing to watch.

662322920.name: Colored beautyful city near to Puebla
662322920.author: a TripAdvisor user
662322920.reviewBody:
Very near , 20min with Uber, to Puebla
Nice view from the pyramid to downtown
The downtown is colored beautyful , esp. when sun is down
it is worth visit Cholula

659874205.name: A symbolic summary of the conquest
659874205.author: a TripAdvisor user
659874205.reviewBody:
In many tourist announcements on Mexico you will see the picture of a Catholic church on the top of an enormous pyramid, with the smoking Popocatépetl volcano looming in the background: it is the picture of the "Great Pyramid" of San Pedro Cholula. This site symbolically sums up the story of the conquest of the New World by the Spanish: the pre-columbine cultures were crushed under the European culture and their sacred (the pyramid) were buried under the European sacred (the church). Visiting this place will make you better understand the story of the conquest.

The pyramid is said to be the biggest monument on earth, twice as large as the pyramid of Cheops in Cairo, Egypt.  Actually, the Cholula pyramid is lower than the Cheops pyramid (66 metres, compared to about 140 metres), but it is much larger at the base (450 metres, compared to 230 metres), so that its total volume is much larger. The pyramid was built by the Toltecs in various successive steps, starting from the 3rd century: periodically, the size of the pyramid was increased by adding a new layer of stones to the previous one, and the last addition was presumably made in the 9th century. A tunnel excavated at the base of the pyramid allows the visitor to appreciate how the works progressed.  

When the Spaniards arrived, they decided not to demolish this monument, but they partially covered it with a layer of earth; then they built a church on the top. Many trees grow on the pyramid, whose sides have a rather small slope; an easy staircase climbs to the top, and admission is free. The church has no special artistic merits, but the views from there are awesome: the view extends to the city of Puebla and to the mountains surrounding the Puebla plains; the frightful Popocatepétl volcano dominates the scene from above your head.

The site is in the Municipality of San Pedro Cholula (which is one of the three Municipalities composing the agglomeration of Cholula: the other two are San Andrés Cholula and Santa Isabel Cholula). Half an hour is sufficient for the visit, but you will probably like to stay more. Just in front of the pyramid there are various restaurants and coffee-shops.

658904324.name: The largest pyramid does not disappoint
658904324.author: a TripAdvisor user
658904324.reviewBody: Very beautifully curated and taken care of. You can easily spend a couple of hours on your own. A guide might enlighten more.

651873077.name: Incredible experience - see the museum first!
651873077.author: a TripAdvisor user
651873077.reviewBody: Incredible experience in many ways!  The (free) walk to the Church at the top of the great pyramid alone is outstanding, try to stay until the sun sets behind a stunning skyline of active volcano Popacatepetl and snow-topped Ixtaccihuatl.  There is a fee to enter the archaeological zone, which includes a separate walk through tunnels left from earlier excavations of the pyramid (NOT appropriate for claustrophobes!!!).  There is a remarkable plaza with altars, and signage in Spanish and English. But what I found most incredible were the many layers of construction exposed. The site could be confusing for visitors, which explains its mixed reviews here. So I have a strong recommendation: visit the Museo Regional de Cholula beforehand! It is a new museum, NOT the museum which is included in the ticket price and has some tired exhibits (Museum de Sitio de Cholula). In contrast, Museo Regional has stunning artifacts, excellent explanations of volcanoes, geography, and PreHispanic glyphs, and best of all it has videos and digital interpretation (in English and Spanish) which help the visitor understand the multi-layered Pyramid construction, and its importance in the story of Mexico. After seeing the Museum, we were eager to explore the Pyramid itself, and were able to appreciate its status as the largest pyramid in the world, in both its volume and the size of its base.

651579203.name: Must see if staying in the vicinity of Puebla
651579203.author: a TripAdvisor user
651579203.reviewBody:
We took a taxi there and back from our hotel in the historic centre of puebla. Took about 30 mins as a lot if traffic and only cost £6 each way. 

The archaeological site is just off from the Zocalo so very accessible. Entrance fee of 75 pesos. Your visit starts with an amazing walk through the tunnels under the pyramid, much of which is now covered in grass so looks like a big hill with a beautiful church on top. The walk takes about 10 mins. You can stand upright st all times but it is narrow. You could skip this part if you feel you might get claustrophobic but it is fascinating. Unfortunately no explanations though in any language.

After walking through the pyramid you visit the site of the excavations and there is good explanatory panels in Spanish and English. The site is quite large even though only parts of a few of the buildings have been uncovered. I found it quite impressive and very interesting. At the end you can climb up part of a temple. Steep stairs and unfortunately  nothing to see at the top.

The church on top of the pyramid hill can be visited for free. Nothing to make it stand out from some of the fantastic interiors of churches in Puebla but good views.
Great visit and Cholula is a nice little town to wander around with some good eateries.

649238645.name: A bust
649238645.author: a TripAdvisor user
649238645.reviewBody: The easiest way to get there was with a car. I went with UBER and it took about 15-20 mins and was. It expensive by American standards . Public transit would have been about 40 mins. That being said, the day was a bust in my opinion. The excavations were unimpressive compared to others I have see around the world. I climbed the steps to the top and was dissapojntoas there was nothing at the top and nowhere to go but down. The church at the top was a church; if you\u2019ve see one, you\u2019ve seen many of them. It was nice but again unimpressive to me. The view was nice but again, it was just the valley and the minntains in the distance. The best part of the day was the pins cokada ice cream. I wouldn\u2019t bother going there unless you have plenty of time and nothing to do.

646169963.name: Claustrophobics BEWARE!
646169963.author: a TripAdvisor user
646169963.reviewBody: We didn\u2019t do our homework so were too far into the tunnels before my very claustrophobic niece and my slightly less claustrophobic self realized what we had got ourselves into. The tunnels are just big enough for an average size adult to walk upright one abreast, and are a couple of hundred meters long with corners so you can never see the way out. My niece started to panic and I only didn\u2019t in an effort to keep her from getting worse. We hated every eternal second, and SHAME on the INAH for not putting up large warning signs. If there are any, we certainly didn\u2019t see them.

646126518.name: Amazing view, great walk
646126518.author: a TripAdvisor user
646126518.reviewBody: Going to Cholula is always a great experience... The view is never the same but always amazing! Give yourself the chance to spend some hours learning about what was the biggest pyramid, visiting the chapel and taking unforgettable pictures! This is good for all ages, but be careful if not allowed to walk stairs.

646037478.name: Historic Pyramid
646037478.author: a TripAdvisor user
646037478.reviewBody: Beautiful historic pyramid.  Great entertainment around the area, great food and overall a great experience.

645816993.name: real nice, different how you can walk through it
645816993.author: a TripAdvisor user
645816993.reviewBody: learn about how it was several civilizations that kept building on top of the previous one.  Interesting how the spanards came and built a church on the top.  General due to the altitude of about 7k ft it is not too hot. if you are in the sun especially in the summer, you will probable want a big hat.

644842701.name: Said to be largest in the world
644842701.author: a TripAdvisor user
644842701.reviewBody: And it has a Catholic Church perched on top.  Most of the pyramid is buried under soil and grass, only the back part is visible.  BUT, you get to walk inside of the pyramid through tunnels and see models of what this place looked like in an adjacent museum.  The interior walk can be claustrophobic.

643257981.name: Big pyramid with great views
643257981.author: a TripAdvisor user
643257981.reviewBody: We went in the tunnels, but do NOT go if you\u2019re even a bit claustrophobic.  You have to go through the whole thing because there\u2019s no room to turn back.  It is an easy walk and cool inside and there is lighting.

641851278.name: Cholula Highlight
641851278.author: a TripAdvisor user
641851278.reviewBody: Cholula is easily accessible by bus from Puebla.   Go to the station at 6 Pointe and Calle 13 Nte.  You will not have to wait long for a 45 minute ride to Cholula for $7.5 Pesos.  I recommend getting off at the museum below the old pyramid for good sunny side photo op then walk to the right of the museum around the base to the ramp up the hill to the catholic church.  At the ramp is also the terminal for the tourist train from Puebla Centro.  Another option if its 3 times a day schedule fits yours.  The pyramid also has paid for tours of a portion of its interior.  Did it on a previous trip and it was worth while.  The views from the top and a peek inside the church is warranted.  The rest of the Magic Town of Mexico is noted for its very big Zocalo and several more catholic churches.

639621039.name: Visit to the great Cholula archeological area
639621039.author: a TripAdvisor user
639621039.reviewBody: Beatiful experience walking inside the pyramid for a little more than 1 hour and a tour guide help to understand the place, the people and the construction

637133642.name: Don\'t miss a visit to the largest pyramid in the world!!
637133642.author: a TripAdvisor user
637133642.reviewBody: I have to say that until my visit to Mexico in November 2018, I have never heard of this pyramid. I was truly surprised to find out  not only of its existence, but also of the fact that it happens to be the largest pyramid in the world! Don\'t look for a conventional pyramid - this one actually looks like a large mountain with a beautiful church on top. You can climb the stairs (takes about 20 minutes) to the top and catch some breath-taking views. You can also visit the church itself. Wear comfortable shoes. No photos are allowed inside the church, but you can sneak in a shot or two without a flash. There is a man-made underground tunnel you can visit, which shows you the different levels of the ground and how the pyramid actually looked when it was built. Note that the tunnel is very narrow and not too tall, so if you are claustrophobic, you may want to reconsider visiting it. Before you visit the site, the tunnel or the church, I\'d suggest reading about these sites ahead of time, so you have an idea of the significance of what you are seeing. Otherwise, you can hire a private tour guide to show you around. This was an unforgettable visit. I would highly recommend it!

636762601.name: Wow!  Largest in Mexico
636762601.author: a TripAdvisor user
636762601.reviewBody: Most of this Pyramid is still covered as it has a massive church on top of it, and is a whole mountain.  The trip through the tunnels (built by archeologists) and the tour of the ancient temples and altars is great.

633682685.name: Fun and interesting
633682685.author: a TripAdvisor user
633682685.reviewBody: Not even a day trip from Puebla.  It\'s about 30 minutes from the Zocalo by cab and well worth it.  Be sure to wander through the tunnels and climb to the top.

631330464.name: Easily accessible archeological site
631330464.author: a TripAdvisor user
631330464.reviewBody: We took a taxi from central Puebla City to Cholula for the day for $120 pesos one way.  We climbed to the top to see the Church, which we were unable to enter as there was a service taking place on Sunday then down and along the path to the pyramid site.  We did not have a guide but the few signs are both Spanish and in English so a bit of history was learned.  The is an awesome open air market next with much to look at and purchase for reasonable prices.

621986010.name: Good view
621986010.author: a TripAdvisor user
621986010.reviewBody: This archeological zone is really good, specially if you know the history behind it. It is the biggest pyramid in the world, which is awesome and you can actually go on top! the pyramid itself is covered because of the Spanish Conquest, but you can actually go inside (not sure about the price, but it\u00b4s free for students with ID). You can pay for a tour guide in there, and they\u00b4ll tell you everything there is to know about the history of the place. When you get to the top, the view is amazing! You can see all of Cholula and some parts of Puebla.

621173746.name: A  nice experience   Gabriela Ls
621173746.author: a TripAdvisor user
621173746.reviewBody: The pyramids of Cholula is an archaeological zone that I particularly like and recommend it as a place to visit. It is the largest pyramid in the world and a beauty to appreciate. It has many small areas that leave us great culture and knowledge. It has a large pyramid and on it is the Shrine of Our Lady of Remedies, which was built in the colonial era by the Spanish conquistadors, in the interior you can see an altar to the virgin neoclassical style very beautiful. Personally it is a great place that takes you to know a little of the essence of Mexico and which we must know to feed our cultural diversity. \nGabys

619594441.name: Very Nice
619594441.author: a TripAdvisor user
619594441.reviewBody: I recommend hiring a guide, however, I don\u2019t know if any of them speak good English. We speak Spanish, so it wasn\u2019t an issue for us. The guide\u2019s explanation was very interesting. It\u2019s worth it to walk up to the church for the views. The area is very beautiful, and the view of the church on the hill is striking.

614351238.name: Beautiful place!
614351238.author: a TripAdvisor user
614351238.reviewBody: Cortez called it "the most beautiful city outside Spain\u201d. By the time he arrived, it was the second-largest city in the Aztec empire. The Pyramid is covered and only parts of it are visible, after doing a lot of research I opted just to go to the church on top as on my way up I was able to look at some of the structures on the side. \n

613966886.name: The largest pyramid in Americas
613966886.author: a TripAdvisor user
613966886.reviewBody: Just the largest pyramid in Americans is some kind of hill with a church on top. The site is impressive and clean .

611067204.name: Disappointing
611067204.author: a TripAdvisor user
611067204.reviewBody: The pyramid is under a hill, with a small chapel on top. There is an underground tunnel thru the pyramid, but almost nothing to see. Barely worth the price (free).

606424884.name: layers and layers of prehispanic history- Tlachihualtepetl
606424884.author: a TripAdvisor user
606424884.reviewBody: How often can you say that you went into a pyramid? Even more into the largest based pyramid in the world! Covered by nature and humans (colonized by Spaniards), now only fragments of this pyramid can be seen from the outside, but the visit includes entering into some of the different layers forming this structure.\nMake sure you have a certified tours guide with you, and the experience grows much more!

603094393.name: Amazing and unbelievable construction
603094393.author: a TripAdvisor user
603094393.reviewBody: Entry cost is around U$3.50 per person and is surely worth 3.5 billion U$!!! Amazing to imagine what happened more than 2,500 years ago in this place. Do hire a zone-guide for he/she will explain secrets which otherwise you will miss. Entry ticket includes the tunnels, church climb and charming Museo del Sitio.

602342889.name: Interesting but...
602342889.author: a TripAdvisor user
602342889.reviewBody: The pyramid is huge but the problem is that you cannot see much of it. It is unexcavated and covered in foliage. The tunnels underneath are open but I wish they would allow access to all the routes. You can only go on one level. The tunnels go up and down and there are many routes. There are some ruins scattered around the pyramid but nothing of great significance, in my opinion. I did enjoy going there but I found Teotihuacan more interesting as you can see and climb the whole pyramid. The town is quaint and pleasant and I found a very good Pakistani restaurant that served the best nan (bread) that I have ever tasted.

601776465.name: Largest underground pyramid in the world!
601776465.author: a TripAdvisor user
601776465.reviewBody: Fabulous day out in Cholula. Easy to get to by car or there is a new option of taking the tourist train from the city centre of Puebla directly to the main area of Cholula, which I believe takes 40 minutes. This is such a stunning little village, which gives you the sense of how life really is in Mexico. The pyramid tour starts by going underground to give you a sense of how it was built and it then continues on to the outside grounds. The tour takes about 1 hour, it was free and we just gave a tip at the end, as we had a really great guide. We can also do the tour without a guide if you like. Fantastic to see the largest pyramid in the world and learn the history of the ancient city. Afterwards you can walk up the church which sits on top of the pyramid. This is also free, but it is very steep, so it\'s worth bringing water. Also good to mention that most of this is in the open and if you go in the summer you will need sunblock and a hat. Really enjoyed this trip to Cholula and if you go to Puebla it is a must see. Very relaxing day away from the big city and so much to do there.

601265714.name: One of the biggest pyramid in the world
601265714.author: a TripAdvisor user
601265714.reviewBody: Outstanding site, it goes together with the church on top. Perfect example on how the Spanish Catholics wanted to erase the culture of the natives.

592011239.name: Fascinating place
592011239.author: a TripAdvisor user
592011239.reviewBody: It\'s fascinating to drive into Cholula and see a church atop a pyramid. Even more interesting to walk through tunnels created by archaeologists to see inside the pyramid. I also enjoyed buying crafts as I made my way up to the church. Don\'t miss this!

591297719.name: Surprisingly impressive
591297719.author: a TripAdvisor user
591297719.reviewBody: The Cholula Pyramid is impressive, once you understand what you are looking at. Be sure to do a little internet research before you visit. For the 70 pesos admission, you walk under the pyramid and view the various stages of its construction. The tunnel is tight, so maybe skip it you are claustrophobic.  After that you walk around the outside and view the surface excavations. Finally, climb to the top, view the nice church, and catch the great view. There is an optional museum, 40 pesos,  which is nice, but not memorable.

587202241.name: Beautiful!
587202241.author: a TripAdvisor user
587202241.reviewBody: What an interesting place! 5 pyramids were build over time on top of each other plus the church...quiet a history! We recommend the tour that shows you the ruins of the pyramid(s) and the tunnels in the pyramids made by archeologists. Very impressive! Be aware the fotos you see of the church and Popocat\u00e9petl are photoshopped although you see the Popocat\u00e9petl very well from top of the hill. Cholula (part of Puebla) is very pretty and worth a visit. We stayed in am airbnb just below the church and probably build on parts of the pyramid. The pyramid is 4x bigger than the Pyramid Del Sol and 6x bigger than Egypt\'s Gize pyramid....

586024688.name: Must see the great pyramid with the beautiful church on the top
586024688.author: a TripAdvisor user
586024688.reviewBody: There is a lot to learn about Aztec history at this huge pyramid - one of the biggest in the world. There is a beautiful Spanish church at the top of the pyramid which requires one to walk up a relatively steep slope - only undertake this if you don\'t have any health issues.  It is on the route for all tours that go to Puebla and Cholula and not to be missed

578095209.name: Unfortunately not well managed
578095209.author: a TripAdvisor user
578095209.reviewBody: It seems the government has invested resources to make this attraction more accessible. There is an ultra modern train from Puebla to practically the entrance of the pyramid that runs several times a day and the area is well kept and clean. I found myself waiting for an hour to buy a ticket to enter the pyramid but the ticket person never showed up. When I walked away there were probably 20-30 people waiting, including guides that are there to make a living out of the visitors. I found this very unfortunate and will have to wait until next time to visit.

574631171.name: Who would have known, a Pyramid under a Church
574631171.author: a TripAdvisor user
574631171.reviewBody: We were late getting to the site so we returned early the following day.  This is the largest pyramid in the New World.  When you get to the site, there is a church at the top.  Now, this pyramid is completely different than any other in Mexico.  We see others tower to the sky.  This one happens to be buried but it\'s size is measured not by it\'s height, but it\'s outline.  If you do not speak Spanish you can get a guide who speaks English.  I am not certain if other languages are provided.  This pyramid was built nine levels high and you will be able to see those levels under ground.  It is truly amazing.  Not recommended for the handicap or people who may have health issues.  The tunnels are narrow and not very high, so, there is a lot of bending.  I would recommend seeing, it is just so uniquely different.

572778936.name: Worth a visit
572778936.author: a TripAdvisor user
572778936.reviewBody:
There's not much to see of the pyramid itself as it's buried mostly. The church built on top of it is the big photo opportunity as are the views from the top.

You can get to the top and walk around the pyramid for free but if you want to go through the tunnels below the pyramid and the museum you will need to pay 70 Pesos entry.

The tunnels are interesting enough but don't expect to see much, just a few different types of stonework. The museum, which is across the road from the ticket booth and tunnel entrance is small with a few exhibits but the model of the pyramid is worth seeing to get an idea of what's below the soil.

If you're in Puebla you can get there for around 120 Pesos by taxi. There is a collectivo but I didn't check it out. Alternatively you can do it as part of a tour from Puebla or Mexico City.

572771767.name: Nice experience
572771767.author: a TripAdvisor user
572771767.reviewBody: The place is breathtaking. Go visit with comfortable shoes, the church on top of the hill it\u2019s beautiful. It was worth the long walk for sure!

571738605.name: Largest Pyramid in Mexico or the Americas
571738605.author: a TripAdvisor user
571738605.reviewBody: Hugh archeological site. Very quick and cheap uber from Puebla (the trains seems to run very seldom). Is huge and hot and surely not as thrilling as Teotichuan or Monte Alban or the Mayan sites. But if you are in Peubla, you should go. Also several cool churches in Cholula.

570318474.name: Must see from the inside!
570318474.author: a TripAdvisor user
570318474.reviewBody: Largest pyramid in the world...how amazing is that!   Best part of visiting the Great Pyramid is going inside and walking thru it!  It was an experience.   Outdoors you can climb the pyramid via steps or ramp (recommend the ramp)   early morning is best as you get a great view of the Popocatepetl afterwards clouds cover it.  You can also walk around the outdoor pyramid...lots of history and descriptions.

570184072.name: A Great Example of One-Upmanship
570184072.author: a TripAdvisor user
570184072.reviewBody: History is replete with one society taking over the wonders of a previous society and incorporating them into their own. This is such a marvelous example with a beautiful church sitting on top of one of the largest pyramids in the world.

569548051.name: Interesting historic place, a must in town
569548051.author: a TripAdvisor user
569548051.reviewBody: Every visitor in Cholula must take a look at the archeological place and the tunnels undernieth the pyramid and church. This is the biggest pyramid in terms of extension and volume in the world.

566352713.name: Very nice
566352713.author: a TripAdvisor user
566352713.reviewBody: Once you buy a ticket, you begin by walking through the tunnels beneath the pyramid. There is no clear signage down there, which is a bit confusing because there are different turnoffs. Anyway, we just kept walking to the end of each tunnel and eventually exited to the outside through glass doors. Again, no signs. Once outside, you just go to the right and start climbing up to the church at the top. There are bathroom signs outside the church leading back down the hill... but no bathrooms. It made for a fun half hour walking up to the top and enjoying the scenery.

562554436.name: Great pyramid of Cholula was just that "Great" plus Danza de los Voladores
562554436.author: a TripAdvisor user
562554436.reviewBody: We visited Cholula recently with out tour group. We were told how this is the largest pyramid in the world. Not your typical Mexican pyramid but most definitely a must visit place.  After you purchase your tickets you start the tour going underneath the pyramid in tunnels built by the archaeologists and come out on the other side. A fairly long tour of over a couple of hours and quite a bit of walking. Near the end of the tour you have an opportunity to climb a section of the pyramid. Lastly there is a market place for souvenirs, then we had the opportunity to  pitch in a few pesos and view the Danza de los Voladores,  Dance of the flyers, what an afternoon.

560827322.name: Signature landmark
560827322.author: a TripAdvisor user
560827322.reviewBody: Last October 2017 the church atop the pyramid was closed by the earthquake. Now in February 2018, we climbed the stairs and trail to the top. Well worth the effort. The church is magnificent and the views outstanding.

559862100.name: Amazing!
559862100.author: a TripAdvisor user
559862100.reviewBody: Take the time to visit this incredible pyramid! The largest in the world. Pay the small entrance fee and visit the museum across the street then wander through the tunnels that take you through the bottom of the pyramid. If you are lucky enough to have a guide as I did, you will learn some amazing tnings! Definetly a must see!

558931513.name: Well worth a visit!
558931513.author: a TripAdvisor user
558931513.reviewBody: We were staying in Puebla with an Intrepid trip and caught an Uber to Cholula to check this place out. Way cheaper and easier than any form of PT, and simply bought a coffee and used their wifi to get one back. We walked up the top to the gorgeous yellow church and then also checked out the underground tunnels and ruins. It can be a little confusing as things are not well signposted (nor much english) but we enjoyed our visit all the same.

553532293.name: Huge
553532293.author: a TripAdvisor user
553532293.reviewBody: The museum has a model that is useful to view before you enter the tunnels. The tunnels are long and narrow with less than 6 foot head room. After exiting the tunnels you can walk around the excavated portion of the pyramids.\n\nThe church on top was still closed for access. You can walk to the top but can not enter.

547659089.name: Great Pyramid of Cholula
547659089.author: a TripAdvisor user
547659089.reviewBody: We did not go into the tunnels made by the Archaeologists where they excavated but took photos of it . The Church on top had been closed due to Earthquake damage recently but it was interesting to see the small row of vendors and hear about the removal of artifacts and how they built the 7 Pyramids every 52 years one on top of each other .\n\nThe plaza was set up for a Rock Concert so we did not stay too long and it was getting dark so we headed back to Mexico City on our Tour bus!

543485989.name: interesting place
543485989.author: a TripAdvisor user
543485989.reviewBody: We went in November and the church was closed due to the earthquake. We visited the local museum, which is very informative. We also had a guided tour to the tunnel inside the pyramid (in English). Our tour guide was very knowledgeable and we learnt a lot from him.

541931347.name: Pre earthquake visit
541931347.author: a TripAdvisor user
541931347.reviewBody: Visited prior to the earthquake and really enjoyed the experience. The trek to the church at the top of the pyramid was worth the effort for the views of the volcanoes and Cholula alone. Went through the tunnels inside the pyramid which, although fairly demanding for a tall westerner were fascinating and led to the impressive excavations of the original pyramid, largest by mass of any in the world, and fine views back up to the church,\nThe museum was well worth visiting

540898223.name: Impressive Tunnels
540898223.author: a TripAdvisor user
540898223.reviewBody: The museum may be small but it is worth a visit , it gives you a background to the site , there is a model which suggests what it may have looked  like , there is an excellent reproduction of a wall painting one of which is known as the Mural Of The drunkards which depicts inebriation , what were they drinking maize beer , something stronger?\nThe highlight is of course are the tunnels more than 8 km have been dug , there are 800m accessible to visitors. Walking through the tunnel you can see earlier layers of the building. The church was not accessible when I visited due to the recent earthquake. Well worth a visit.

538346740.name: No access to top
538346740.author: a TripAdvisor user
538346740.reviewBody: Since the earthquake the access to the top and church is closed. Still it is worth walking through the tunnels and around the pyramid. Avoid weekends specially Sundays as there are many visitors. During the week someone is nearly alone.

538190908.name: Great grounds
538190908.author: a TripAdvisor user
538190908.reviewBody: Chalupa is a very quiet town just south of Puebla, we really enjoyed walking the town and seeing all the restaurants and cantinas. The pyramid and the surroundings above the pyramid were very beautiful. The main square was also very nice and we are able to see acrobatics on the pole in the main center square.

533110646.name: earthquake post conditions
533110646.author: a TripAdvisor user
533110646.reviewBody: Unfortunately due to the earthquake damage was done to the Pyramid. However, we were able to enter through the incredible tunnel to view the grounds at the base. We plan to return in Jan 2018. This is a wonder not to be missed if you are in the area. Admission is free on Sunday.

529694718.name: Awesome experience
529694718.author: a TripAdvisor user
529694718.reviewBody: The pyramid tunnels were worth the experience. The church at the top is currently closed because of the latest earthquake. The large museum is also closed because of the same reason but you can visit the grounds and read all of the well written history. I think this was one of my favorite things to do in Mexico. Also you can see the volcanos from the pyramid.

526679132.name: Great place to visit!
526679132.author: a TripAdvisor user
526679132.reviewBody: This is a great place to visit if you are in Cholula, it is very close to the church which I would also recommend visiting. You can go inside the pyramids, if you don\'t like being in enclosed spaces I would not recommend this. \n\nAround the area is a market as well as the famous \'flying men\'. All in all, a visit to this attraction makes a perfect day out.

517474330.name: Worth a trip if you have time to kill in Puebla
517474330.author: a TripAdvisor user
517474330.reviewBody: This is a nice little day trip from Puebla. You can take the bus from the Cholula Bus station on Avenida 6 /Calle 13.\nI entered the site using the tunnel entrance, which would have been great except for the Tourist Guides doing their business. The tunnel is only wide enough for one person, so the private guide ahead of us held up everyone trying to walk through the tunnel, as he stopped at various points to do his talk. The management of the site should put a stop to this - the tunnel is a small, dark space and there were children crying as we waited for the guide to hurry up.\nAnyway, once we made it out into the sunlight again it was nice to walk up to the Santuario and also to explore the parts of the site that have been excavated. Before I visited I didn\'t know that the Great Pyramid is covered in shrub, but it was interesting to visit nonetheless.

516801627.name: Beautiful Place to See
516801627.author: a TripAdvisor user
516801627.reviewBody: Beautiful relic of the past. Though I caution that if you are claustrophobic, you may kind of freak out as I did and I have mild/average claustrophobia. The walk through the pyramid is about 10 mins with low traffic, longer if there are tour groups in there.

516464094.name: Must see in Puebla
516464094.author: a TripAdvisor user
516464094.reviewBody: This is an easy half-day (or full-day if you explore the town of Cholula). Cholula is like a suburb of Puebla. It is (alleged) to have the town with the highest number of churches (or colonial churches). The keyword is alleged. \nI am sure there are other ways, but a 15 - 20 min, taxi ride from the center will bring you to the zona arqueologico where you will see the church at the top of the hill. The church of the virgin of remedies. The hill -is- the pyramid (or at least part of it). First, you stroll through the passages at the base of the pyramid. When you get out, you walk up towards the top of the hill, to the church. When you go up, you have fantastic views of the town of Cholula AND the two volcanoes, Popocatepetl (still fuming) and the other one with even a harder name (her eruption was so violent, it blew the cone).\nWe did not have time to get into town but I heard that it is a college town with lots of hipster hangouts and you will several beautiful churches and other historic buildings from the top which you will want to visit. If you just limit to the pyramid and the church, it is a half day. If you go into town, full day (or more, why not?). Will definitely return.

515232444.name: Claustrophobic for someone my size.
515232444.author: a TripAdvisor user
515232444.reviewBody: I\'m 6\'3" and not overweight and the tunnels under the pyramid, while well preserved made me extremely claustrophobic for some reason. Several times I almost turned around and went back out the entrance. \n\nFortunately it was crowed and I basically ran through the tunnels to the end.  I didn\'t know I didn\'t like small spaces. It clearly I don\'t.  So if you\'re at all like me, google it online and just go up to the church via one of the other methods.

514560324.name: Wished we saw more of the pyramid
514560324.author: a TripAdvisor user
514560324.reviewBody: I think as a day trip, it is impossible to fit Cholula pyramid in.  But historically it is amazing to wonder how such a large structure escaped the knowledge of the Spaniard when they built the church at its peak, and how so much soil covered the structure and the work required to study it.  Another time... I will return.

509748719.name: dissapointing
509748719.author: a TripAdvisor user
509748719.reviewBody: We were expecting a lot more - even through the book did say that it was all covered in grass.  A shame because it could be anything.  The Church at the top is beautiful and you have good views of city.

503753511.name: awesome experience inside
503753511.author: a TripAdvisor user
503753511.reviewBody: Yes, this pyramid has since grown over and looks like a large hill. But walking through the middle of it is awesome. There are an extended series of tunnels in the pyramid and the path that you can walk through is extensive. The views from the top of the hill were also stunning. We thought it was definitely worth the trip from Puebla.

501331767.name: Pyramid looks like a hill
501331767.author: a TripAdvisor user
501331767.reviewBody: The idea of the great pyramid of Cholula is great! It is an ancient pyramid, which is the biggest in the world, per the base, but in reality, it looks like a hill with a church on top. The tunnels in the pyramid and the ruins are nice, but I would suggest paying for a guide, since it is hard to tell what things are.

498277183.name: Largest on earth!
498277183.author: a TripAdvisor user
498277183.reviewBody: Pyramid of giZa whaaat?! How has no body discussed this it is very strange and such a hidden gem. So much of it still needs to be uncovered but I loved every second of this visit. That\'s us at the very top of the pyramid where a catholic church sits.

492991211.name: pyramid or hill
492991211.author: a TripAdvisor user
492991211.reviewBody: It\'s the largest pyramid by volume, but I feel like walking up a hill. The narrow tunnels (entrance fee) are interesting and 360 view from top. Don\'t compare it with Egypt pyramid otherwise disappointed.

488223158.name: Great views from the top!
488223158.author: a TripAdvisor user
488223158.reviewBody: We have visited the Pyramid of Cholula many times and it is always a pleasure to go to the top. The pyramid itself is not excavated, so it looks more like a small hill. Anyhow from it\'s volume it is the biggest pyramid in the world. You can see on the west side a restored part of it. On top is an old church that was build by the Spanish. The views from the top are outstanding! Go there on a clear day and you can see the volcanos Popocat\u00e9petl and Iztacc\u00edhuatl, and the La Malinche.\nI believe the tour through the tunnel inside the pyramid is okay but not a highlight.\nThe whole area around the pyramid is nicely remodeled. You can even go from Puebla by the new train to the pyramid now.

487468361.name: Pyramid of Cholula
487468361.author: a TripAdvisor user
487468361.reviewBody:
Beautiful place. Green grass, full beautiful trees and colorful flowers to compliment Cholulas colorful city.

The pyramid is incredibly large, and still so much of it is uncovered. 

450 meters each side at the base & 66 meters tall.

On the top of the hill over looking the pyramid there is a beautiful church that you can hike up to.

If you look behind, you have a great view of the Volcano smoking in the mountains.

You can even go into the pyramid underground, there is one entrance and one exit as they blocked off the other secret tunnels. ( if your clostaphobic I wouldn't recommend going in).

Reccomendations: 

Wear comfortable shoes,
Bring water, 
Snacks, 
Toilet paper or wipes for washroom,
Light back pack (if hiking),
& Money for the abundance of souvenirs you can purchase on the way out,
In the arena if you clap, it will echo (fun to try),
Eat before you go.

486704935.name: Impressive Pyramid "Mountain"
486704935.author: a TripAdvisor user
486704935.reviewBody: The pyramid is the largest in the New World, and the largest pyramid known to exist in the world today. The original construction took place approximately 2000 years ago. It looks like a massive hill or mountain with a church perched on top. We began by entering the tunnels that were created by archaeologists to provide access to the huge buried structured. The tunnels alone and viewing the construction up close is worth a visit. The climb to the top rewards one with an outstanding view of Cholula.

484855068.name: Interesting site
484855068.author: a TripAdvisor user
484855068.reviewBody: Visited this site during our tour of Mexico.  The village of Cholula is an attractive place in itself, very colourful.\nThe Pyramid is huge and not overly crowded with tourists.  Unfortunately, the tunnels were closed when we visited but it was worthwhile walking around the base of the pyramid.

483269714.name: Worth a Visit!
483269714.author: a TripAdvisor user
483269714.reviewBody: If you\'re in Puebla you must take some time to visit the pyramid of Cholula. In addition to the historical significance, you can get some great views from the top of the hill.

481441170.name: Great place to visit, on a weekend!
481441170.author: a TripAdvisor user
481441170.reviewBody: It\'s a very nice place to visit during a weekend getaway, less than a day is needed to do it.\nWe got there early in the morning and after two to three hours we were over. The view from the top of the hill is really nice, and enjoy the architecture of the church. We also got to visit the ruins of the pyramid, which I got to say are not as impressive as others in the country, but the feeling of being there and connect with the ancient cultures is amazing.\nI loved it as a quick break to explore.

481084208.name: Not your typical pyramid
481084208.author: a TripAdvisor user
481084208.reviewBody: This is not your average pyramid, but it\'s still worth a visit.  The view looks more like a regular mountain with a structure at its peak.  There is a beautiful museum right next to this place that you should definitely visit to learn about what this Great Pyramid of Cholula is all about, in order to appreciate all of its glory.

478269362.name: An amazing place
478269362.author: a TripAdvisor user
478269362.reviewBody: I have heard variations on the story of whether the Spaniards knew the site was man made or not. Either way the pyramid is huge. One of the most photographed places in Mexico - the church on top with Popocat\u00e9petl in the background. Very difficult to mimic this shot unless you  try early in the morning after it has rained

476174982.name: World largest and the most unknown pyramid
476174982.author: a TripAdvisor user
476174982.reviewBody: No-one knows it exists. At least outside Mexico. Yet, it\'s the biggest (my volume) pyramid in the world. Only small portition of it has been dug from the ground because on top of the hill that covers it is a church. You can enter the tunnels of the pyramid also, to travel through it, although, only small part of the tunnels are open to explore. Climb to the top of the pyramid (hill) for an amazing view of the surrounding city.

473014560.name: A Developing Site
473014560.author: a TripAdvisor user
473014560.reviewBody: Only a small portion of the entire complex has been processed.  I still highly recommend it for those interested in archaeology.   It would take years to finish excavating, but what has been exposed is well worth the trip.

470349338.name: "tourist train"
470349338.author: a TripAdvisor user
470349338.reviewBody: I took the tourist train from Puebla to the pyramid in Cholula. \nThe end station in Cholula was right next to the base of the pyramid. From the station it was easy to navigate around the pyramid area. The views from the train were interesting to see the two cities from a different view points aka perspective. The mountains were able to seen in the surrounding area

469230656.name: The museum, tunnels, and hike up the mountain all make for a memorable visit!
469230656.author: a TripAdvisor user
469230656.reviewBody:
For both of my group study abroad trips to central Mexico, we spent our first full day in Cholula, with most of the time spent at the base and atop the pyramid. The Great Pyramid (though resembling a tree covered miniature mountain) can be seen for quite some distance away, with the yellow church at the peak attracting most of your attention. We began our tour at the museum located at the base of the pyramid, which highlighted the history of the pyramid and the sad events that happened to the native Cholulans during the Spanish's conquest of Mexico in the early 16th century. The original artifacts, models, and exhibits are truly unique, as national museums only briefly touch on Cholula as a whole - this museum is a fitting tribute to this town, so go! The museum is definitely a must-see, and not just because a tour of the tunnels and ruins of the pyramid is included in the price of admission. 

A museum tour guide gives you an incredible tour of the museum and then to the tunnels located underneath the Great Pyramid. I'm saddened to see recent reviews that claim that the tunnel is currently closed. This may simply be due to the fact that there are occasional structural dangers, and closing the tunnel is in the public's best interest. However, if I remember correctly, there is a locked gate at the tunnel entrance that is only accessible by someone at the museum, thus, you need to pay the small admission price. In any case, the tunnels merely give you a broader scope of how deep underneath this "mountain" the original architects went. It's amazing to see how sophisicated indigenous people were, especially when compared to the great European civilizations during the same time period. 

At the tunnel's exit, there is a pathway that eventually leads to a side of the pyramid that has many archaeological excavations. Before you get there, there are a few street vendors. Here is where I tried fried grasshopper for the first time, all for the sake of being Mr. Outgoing! I really liked the candy vendor, and the fact that the lady gave samples of nearly everything to our group of 10 before we decided which one to buy and share among ourselves. There is also a vendor that sells small art pieces, all of which make for great souvenirs for loved ones back home. 

To get to the archaeological excavations, I believe there is a fence and entrance that only allows those with museum tickets to pass through. After passing through, you get the best view of the yellow church sitting atop the pyramid, as well as a grand scope of what the pyramid originally looked like before centuries of tree and shrub growth made this into a hidden gem. Many stone engravings and steps are exposed, with much of the area surrounding the flat base also being part of the original city built around the pyramid. This is definitely a time when you want a knowledgeable guide, so pay the small museum admission price and go with a guide! There are also several cactus types around, including those used for the pulque drink. Learning about this historic alcoholic beverage, and drinking it in a nearby store later that day, was a nice addition. Finally, there is a miniature pyramid you are able to climb a little farther down (which prepares you for climbing the grand daddy of them all, the Pyramid of the Sun and Moon at Teotihucuan).

On to climbing the pyramid and seeing that yellow church up close! Before getting to the cobblestone walkway that partly encircles the side of the pyramid, you pass several large vendors in a street market. If this is your first stop in Mexico, just know that you'll see these same items over and over again. If you're in a rush, or don't know how to bargain and get stuck with a high price, just wait for the next market scene. Puebla has a beautiful market, especially on Sundays, when everything is closed for this family-orientated society. However, walking up the hill brings many more vendors, including many hats and food opportunities. I would try the street food every chance you get! (Though I've been advised not to try big meals via street vendors, though fruits and candies are an exception in my eyes). The hill isn't too bad of a hike, and in no time, you are at a final flight of steps that lead you to that yellow church you've been seeing all day. At the top, the church is surrounded by a courtyard that allows you to look in all directions. There are several mountains on the horizon. Seeing the residential and commercial neighborhoods from this height is pretty cool too. Take a quick peak (or send a prayer) inside the church, as the art and architecture is nice (though there are dozens of similar-awesome churches in central Mexico). 

This entire attraction should be at least a half-day visit, followed by walking the market and store scene in downtown Cholula. Having lunch by the main park, drinking pulque, and relaxing in a historic colonial town in Mexico isn't a bad way to spend an afternoon. Enjoy the rest of your exploration of Mexico! iAmo Mexico!

468173866.name: Don\'t waste your money
468173866.author: a TripAdvisor user
468173866.reviewBody: This is probably the worst tourist site I\'ve visited in 2 months in Mexico. The entrance is now M$70 (same as Teotihuacan) to get in, good luck finding the entry to the site, nothing is marked and you need to keep walking around till you stumble across it. The outdoor archeological site can be seen from the street through a wire fence or from the walk to the church on top of the hill that is free for an overview. It was really disappointing and nothing worth seeing really. Signs in English and Spanish tell you what the pile of rock used to be and how they were decorated but they could say anything. It\'s maybe a 15 min stroll if you walk very slowly. The only thing I thought would make the site worthwhile were the tunnels in to the Pyramid but after walking around trying to find the entry to them learnt they were closed. The included museum is very basic with 2 rooms. The only good thing way the model.  Would recommend the church and walk around outside.

464292661.name: Museum is a mixture, tunnels closed
464292661.author: a TripAdvisor user
464292661.reviewBody: It was a shame that the tunnels were closed. Much of the site is not excavated. Climb to the church if you can. It is a great view. The church is very well preserved 19th century. The. Museum is eclectic from artefacts of the era to contemporary art from Oaxaca. I loved the fantastical Ali bride critters. Even if they didn\'t have anything to o with the site. Lovely cafe/gift shop, but slow service.

464111318.name: You can go inside the pyramid
464111318.author: a TripAdvisor user
464111318.reviewBody: The whole complex is large, with the smaller pyramids and "roads", the climb to the top of the mountain (which used to be the top of the pyramid), where the Church is. It takes some physical level to do it all. The highlight is going inside the large pyramid. Seeing the tunnels, which are very narrow and dark. NOTE: Be aware if you are claustrophobic. They don\'t warn you of this when you buy the tickets. But when we were inside two different people had to be rushed outside as they were starting to go into panic attacks.

460415132.name: Encyclopedic Site
460415132.author: a TripAdvisor user
460415132.reviewBody:
