Although the documentation was not up to usual INAH standards -- many pieces were undated and seemed out of context-- a relatively small anachronistic Olmec head seems to have rolled itself into an section with several stelae and altars.  

This is a marvelous and very long lived archeological park.. some say it dates from the Formative to the post Classic -500bce to 900+AD

It is said to be the largest pyramid in Mexico --- perhaps the tallest..because the Cacaxtla, Tlaxcala site at 10,000m2 certainly sprawls  further horizontally.. 

The underground excavation was not available the day we visited but the vista from the top was spectacular..including an eruption at Pococatpetl. 

The Feathered Serpent and Teotihuacano style talud and framed tablero testify to the site's influences..Warriors from Tlaxcala ultimately aided the conquistadors and felling this gigantic center.

459790838.name: Great exhibitions
459790838.author: a TripAdvisor user
459790838.reviewBody: The tunnels were closed to the sites but there were great museums and exhibitions featuring the volcanos, MesoAmerican history, art and more.     The problem was trying to find where everything was located.  Not many people to help and definitely not in English.   The church above the site gives a great view of the space.

459394651.name: Largest pyramid on earth
459394651.author: a TripAdvisor user
459394651.reviewBody: The great pyramid of Cholula shows the amazing capability of Aztec builders. It is accompanied by smaller pyramids and "roads". On top is a monastery, as can be seen in the excavations.

457686629.name: massive "tourist" attraction
457686629.author: a TripAdvisor user
457686629.reviewBody: Took me a while to find this on site as i didnt really know what i was looking for as the ticket had a photo of ruins in Oaxaca instead? eventually i found a half pyramid the more i looked at it the more i realized that hardly any looked original 4000-6000 years old and at some point had been rebuilt as they were letting people climb it the ruins further down i believe were original and fenced off The whole site itself is massive and i like the museum cafe with amazing roof and grass garden was really well done but this site is expanding fast with lots of new shop units going up so there was lots of mess on the outskirts.This will be a massive tourist attraction in years to come with train line to puebla already put in. God knows what cholula will become as its already traffic chocked on weekends you cannot move for cars.

455682551.name: Tunnels were closed
455682551.author: a TripAdvisor user
455682551.reviewBody: Beautiful grounds, they were working on the tunnels underneath the pyramid, but we went up to the church and had a picnic on the grounds.

449739834.name: Nice half-day trip from Puebla
449739834.author: a TripAdvisor user
449739834.reviewBody: A must-see if you stay in Puebla. Easy accesible by the public transport. There are several cheap buses you can use to get to and from the place. The pyramid itself is massive, there is a museum  and undeground tunnels accessible for tourists. The church was built at the top of the pyramd by Spaniards in times when the pyramid was considered to be just a hill, not a man made construction. Definetely worth to visit,

447600598.name: Excellent!
447600598.author: a TripAdvisor user
447600598.reviewBody:
We toured the site itself and the museum.  I recommend you hire a guide in advance to really understand all of what you are--and aren't--seeing.  Buy your tickets first and start at the museum.  The museum has a great overview of the entire site, much of which is buried beneath earth.  Then tour the tunnel within a layer of the pyramid---highlight of the trip.  Finish on the long way up to the church for amazing views of cholula, Puebla, and the volcano and mountains.  

Lots of stairs/steps.

Go early. We arrived at about 9:45am and that was great.  Even better (more tranquil) to arrive at 9am.  Lots of tourists start arriving between 10 and 10:30am.

Fascinating ruins, loved learning he history of this site.  This pyramid is the largest in the world, as measured by volume.

446453056.name: Okay
446453056.author: a TripAdvisor user
446453056.reviewBody: I didn\'t really enjoy the visit. I mean, they didn\'t really have interesting information to read about the place & it was quite a long walk.

444275126.name: Fascinating site
444275126.author: a TripAdvisor user
444275126.reviewBody: We walked up the ramp to the church before heading down and walking through the pyramid. There was construction going on in front of the visible exterior section of the pyramid and we didn\'t realize that we had missed access to it somewhere along the ramp. We chose not to go back up because we had already seen it from many angles. The pyramid was interesting and the history fascinating. The museum can be reached from Calle 14 Pte. by taking the steps to Calle 8 Nte. It is on the right before Calle 2 Ote. It was small but also interesting.

441139328.name: The largest in the world?!
441139328.author: a TripAdvisor user
441139328.reviewBody: The Great Pyramid is indeed the pyramid with the largest base in the world, in underground of curse but still is worth to see it! Is a lovely walk around the pyramid with the market with traditional mexican handcrafts, then going up to the hill, is a small hike to discover on the top of the pyramid is a tiny church very famous in M\u00e9xico the celebration in this church is in september is worth to visit that month. Of curse the visit isn\u00b4t complete if you don\u00b4t go to the tunel under the mountain, for about 70 MX pesos; you can walk inside the pyramid and get to see amazing piece of humankind history!!! Definitely recommend it!!

440141148.name: Walk under a pyramid lately?
440141148.author: a TripAdvisor user
440141148.reviewBody: This is an amazing spot not only do you get to hike up to a church built on top of a pyramid but then you get to walk through/under that very same pyramid!  The little town itself is a bit too touristy for me personally but there is an amazing craft beer spot nearby called the Beer Box so enjoy your hiking and then some drinking.

440042462.name: Quality historical site, do research before if you don\'t use a guide
440042462.author: a TripAdvisor user
440042462.reviewBody:
Really this is a very interesting place with genuine history. I do recommend that if you don't use a guide, do some research before you go so that you can truly appreciate the experience and understand what is there and the story behind it. 

What makes this place great is that you can actually go inside the pyramid and walk through some of the tunnels and see the stairways-from the few hundred metres of publicly accessible tunnels you can imagine what it was really like inside the pyramid thousands of years ago.

it offers an amazing insight to one of the largest pyramids accessible today.

439912557.name: Largest base Temple
439912557.author: a TripAdvisor user
439912557.reviewBody: It was my first visit to this archeological treasure!!! When you purchase your ticket ($65 pesos for people 12 and up) you will have access to the museum, tunnels, the structures in the back yard, and up to the church. The tunnels are an amazing experience. They are lit and we felt very safe. We got a tour guide that we shared with another visitor and split the cost of $200 pesos. The facility has tons of benches through out the park...clean facilities, and restrooms. I am truly amazed with this location. Once you exit the park you can buy local treats from vendors. This location is a must SEE!!!!!

439632292.name: Beautiful
439632292.author: a TripAdvisor user
439632292.reviewBody: I went in the month of July and have to say it was very beautiful. To get to the church on top of the pyramid there is a small walk up a hill. A little trying but definitely worth it. The scene from the top is beautiful, you are able to see the town and beyond. I also recommend going into the tunnels. If you do not like to be enclosed in small places this may not be for you. With the same ticket you go into see the tunnels you can also see some more of the pyramids. They also have a lot of vendors if you are interested in buying souvenirs.

437955632.name: Good one day trip
437955632.author: a TripAdvisor user
437955632.reviewBody: An interesting part of history. Worth spending a day  free to go up to the church but a bit confusing to get down to the ruins

436239925.name: Nice tour
436239925.author: a TripAdvisor user
436239925.reviewBody: Very interesting tour.  We book an english guide at the ticket office.  The guide was very informative and spoke good english.  Lots of history of the local peoples.  The tour included the pyramid, a small museum, and the archeological site.

435180652.name: Spectacular views
435180652.author: a TripAdvisor user
435180652.reviewBody: Walk up to the top of the church and you will be rewarded with amazing views all the way around, literally appearing to see forever. Beautiful church, and the archeology grounds are well maintained and easy to walk around.

434609883.name: The Good Pyramid of Cholula
434609883.author: a TripAdvisor user
434609883.reviewBody: Okay. This is definitely worth the visit, for sure. The archeological site is very nice and quite interesting, and walking through the tunnels is very cool, but, the pyramid itself doesn\'t LOOK as impressive as it really is. It\'s huge (in width, not height) but you can only see a part of it. You can climb it though, which is cool. Great views of the volcanos if it\'s not cloudy.

434364769.name: Historial Experence
434364769.author: a TripAdvisor user
434364769.reviewBody: \nThis is a great place to learn about the history of the Indians that lived in that area. If you are going to this Pyramid, it is recommend to go the museum of this pyramid before going into the attraction\n

434238968.name: San Andr\u00e9s Cholula, Puebla
434238968.author: a TripAdvisor user
434238968.reviewBody:
San Andrés Cholula is the municipal seat of 
San Andrés Cholula Municipality located in 
the center west of the state of Puebla in 
the central highlands of Mexico, 122 km east 
of Mexico City and eight kilometres west of 
the city of Puebla

431437482.name: Great place in vicinity of Puebla
431437482.author: a TripAdvisor user
431437482.reviewBody: Easily accessed with a colectivo from Puebla. Cholula pyramid is just amazing, and offers the best view I\'ve seen of Popocatepl volcano. My favorite part is standing in front of the main altar. Regarding the tunnels, mind that they are quite long and if you are claustrophobic it may be better to skip them, as going back the same way you came from would be difficult due to other people coming in.\n\nCholula is definitely one of my favorite ruins in Mexico.

430677606.name: The tunnels were my favorite part!
430677606.author: a TripAdvisor user
430677606.reviewBody: It was worth the very quick trip from Puebla. Do NOT miss the tunnels! I would do the tunnels first, and then go up the pyramid.

428991507.name: Walk Inside the Pyramid
428991507.author: a TripAdvisor user
428991507.reviewBody: We spent several hours exploring the Great Pyramid of Cholula.  We took Uber from Puebla and the driver dropped us off near the entrance.  The ticket was a 3 part ticket for each area.  I would highly suggest hiring a local guide.  Prices are set and posted on a sign near the entrance.  I would recommend our guide Alberto.  He was very knowledgeable about the pyramid.  It was interesting to walk through the tunnels under the pyramid.  Alberto explained everything both in the tunnels and outside ruins.  I think we would have missed a lot without a guide.  Lots of walking at the Pyramid so make sure you have comfortable shoes.

428350965.name: Wonderful place in the heart of Cholula
428350965.author: a TripAdvisor user
428350965.reviewBody:
Visited this site with 4 children.
Don't miss the tour inside the piramide(only adults are paying for the enterance). You don't have to take the guided tour. 
Go up all the way to the church on the top of the piramide and enjoy the view of Popo-Itza, Cholula and Puebla.
To see the ruins of the piramide from the outside, youcan access the archiological site opposite to the parking lot.

424159932.name: Must visit
424159932.author: a TripAdvisor user
424159932.reviewBody: A must visit - explore the tunnels and marvel at the opulence of the church. Three layers of history in one.  Amazing views of Chalula too

423130025.name: Truly amazing
423130025.author: a TripAdvisor user
423130025.reviewBody: This blew me away the first time I visited years ago.  Now more of the inside of the pyramid can be accessed. How could the   Spaniards have built a church atop this behemoth?

422519774.name: Skip it and go to Tlaxcala
422519774.author: a TripAdvisor user
422519774.reviewBody: Except for the views from the top this site is not worth visiting. This site is very commercialized and there\'s really not much to see. The museum is not very interesting or informative, there is nothing really unique about the pyramid except for some tunnels that were dug by archaeologists. The church is nice and but there are more interesting churches to visit elsewhere. I suggest you skip this site and go to the city of Tlaxcala where you will find the archaeological site Cacaxtla. This site has ancient murals in beautiful condition and the nearby site of Xochitecatl has a very nice small museum with some unique clay figures that you might not see elsewhere. Plus there are not an overwhelming number of tourists and vendors.

418954297.name: Awsome day in Cholula
418954297.author: a TripAdvisor user
418954297.reviewBody: We had one of our best days visiting the ruin and Church of cholula.  We lucked upon a great guide and enjoyed the history.  The ruins don\'t have any information about them when you walk around so I would recommend getting a guide.  Without him, I think we would have been very bored soon, but he brought it to life.  Thanks Mizraim!

418728810.name: Worth a visit
418728810.author: a TripAdvisor user
418728810.reviewBody: Spent 2 days in Cholula. Such a beautiful place with pyramids, churches and markets. Great for shopping and must walk through the pyramid and see the ruins. Loved it!

415160623.name: Hesitant to recommend
415160623.author: a TripAdvisor user
415160623.reviewBody:
It's a "commercialized" pyramid. 
I didn't expect a pyramid like this.
At first, I thought I would go into a "ruin" and climb the pyramids like I did with other "pyramids" in the world. 
It turns out that when we arrived at the foot of the pyramid, it's a large commercial open air market including circuits, street vendors, and music surrounding the entrance. 
You saw the ruins of the pyramids on the bottom, and then there is a cathedral on the top of the pyramids. From afar, you would think it's a small hill with church on the top. 
It took me 20 minutes to walk up to the top of the church, not a bad climb. 
But budget at least an hour in this place to climb up, check out the church, and browse through booths of street vendors selling foods, souvenirs, and etc. 
I would skip this place if I go to Mexico City again.

414322009.name: Incredible site
414322009.author: a TripAdvisor user
414322009.reviewBody: We stayed in Puebla and hired a taxi and guide for the day, which was well worth the money. This was one of the sites we visited. Apparently, the pyramid is the second largest, although it can\'t be seen having been covered by Earth over the centuries. When the Spaniards arrived, they built a church on the top. The only way to visit the pyramid is to go inside, with a guide. The whole site is vast and still being excavated.

414057589.name: Place full of hostory
414057589.author: a TripAdvisor user
414057589.reviewBody: The price to get in the pyramid is $65 mx. You\'ll spend abput 2 hours there. It is a walking visit, bring comfortable shoes! You\'ll love the place!

412120054.name: Do go and see
412120054.author: a TripAdvisor user
412120054.reviewBody: This is actually the largest pyramid in the world, hidden beneath a huge mountain. There\'s an extensive underground passage with some displays to see. Worth seing and for those who want to learn something extra, there are always english-speaking guides lurking next to the ticket counter, you pay them separately but get the historical background if you wish. If not, just read about it in your travel guide and visit on your own.

408494360.name: Awesome Experience
408494360.author: a TripAdvisor user
408494360.reviewBody: We went there for the day. We walked to the top to see the church and then we did the pyramid and the tunnel. Was so impressive. You have to pay to visit the place.

403768356.name: Interesting place
403768356.author: a TripAdvisor user
403768356.reviewBody: It is supposedly the largest pyramid base in the world. However, the pyramid itself is covered with growth and cannot be seen. You can only climb it to the Church on top. This is an impressive church and also provides good views of surrounding areas.\nYou can enter the Pyramid at your own risk by paying a fee.

403648493.name: Worth it.
403648493.author: a TripAdvisor user
403648493.reviewBody: Paid the 65 pesos to go through the tunnels and see the ruins. While you can look into the ruins for free, it was worth the money! On a clear day, climbing to the church is a good idea for the view, but I would have skipped if the volcanoes were hiding.

402875432.name: Different than other pyramids near Mexico City
402875432.author: a TripAdvisor user
402875432.reviewBody: We enjoyed this pyramid for its differences than many other Zonas Arqueologica near Mexico City - it has great passages under the pyramid that you are able to explore.  Unfortunately there is very little signage in the tunnels, so I would recommend hiring one of the guides who wait near the ticket stand.  Once out of the tunnels we walked up the stairs to visit the church on top of the pyramid.  It was not obvious to us how to get around the climb the few pyramid stairs that there are.  Signage is very lacking at this location.

402021056.name: Not that great
402021056.author: a TripAdvisor user
402021056.reviewBody: It\'s a well kept ruin, and it does have a lot of great things to look at, but the tunnels are just tunnels and to visit the ruins it only takes less than an hour. Kind of hard to get lost in the past here. Lots of vendors around to buy gifts and food.

399356071.name: Amazing
399356071.author: a TripAdvisor user
399356071.reviewBody: I visited the pyramid with my family. First you go through the museum and then they take you inside the pyramid. The tour guide explained all of the history regarding the pyramid. At the end you can claim the pyramid. It was very informative and fun and recommend everyone to go.

399260648.name: Beautiful church and amazing view of the volcanos
399260648.author: a TripAdvisor user
399260648.reviewBody:
This is the grates pyramid in terms of volume in the world. 

There's not much to see not that interesting, other than the story they tell you about it. 

Its a very cheap place you can have the guided tour for about 5 dollars

In the top of the pyramid, Spanish conquerors built a church. Its not hard to get there but be sure you'll get tired getting to the top. Once on the top you can have a great view of the volcanos and the city.

398957683.name: archaelogical site, not complete pyramid
398957683.author: a TripAdvisor user
398957683.reviewBody:
I have enjoyed the pyramids at El Tajin and near Mexico City. They have many complete buildings. Cholula is different. Here most of the pyramid still lies underground. This is a paid visit site. You enter through a long, narrow lighted tunnel that was excavated inside the pyramid. It is a longer walk with no signs, no murals, or anything to see but a long tunnel and side tunnels that are closed by gates, 

Exiting the tunnel you can see a few parts of the large pyramid that have been excavated.  The plaza of the altars is quite interesting and echoes when you clap your hands.

There is a small part of a side pyramid to climb near the end of the site.

Signs are in Spanish and attempts at English. At the time of our visit, signs were poor and an overall map of the site would have been welcomed. Signs refer to various building numbers without a map to tell you where the buildngs are.

It is worth seeing unless you are hoping for a complete pyramid.

Our taxi driver let us off and pointed for us to go up a very long ramp. That ramp leads to the Roman Catholic Church built on the top of the hill inside with remains the pyramid. Unfortunatel we were not looking for the church but the pyramids.

A tourist market and small restaurant are nearby plus many street vendors.

397448309.name: A special place to visit
397448309.author: a TripAdvisor user
397448309.reviewBody:
Wow! We came here as part of a tour with Insolitours and this was one of the highlights of our entire trip. We started in the archaeological zone.
The history of the site is unique and was not aware of it before. Basically you have a community living around a pyramid that was then taken by the Spanish , they killed all and sundry, as locals kept coming to the site, the spanish decided to put a church on top so they could convert them instead. Over time the pyramid has become overgrown to the extent it is not recognisable. However when it was excavated it is one of the biggest pyramids in the world! There is a small and dull museum to one side , then you can walk through some of the tunnels inside the pyramid before scaling it up to the church on top. The views are incredible covering Puebla in one direction and Popocatepetl in the other, as well as Cholula itself.
The church itself is quite small inside.
We also went to the  San Gabriel convent and zocolo opposite which was very picturesque.  On the outskirts of town is a small church at Tonantzintla this was properly weird and wonderful. Not seen anything like this before!

396411120.name: Pyramids
396411120.author: a TripAdvisor user
396411120.reviewBody: Wish they took this site to another level lots to be escavated...lots of buildings are built on the pyramids base.Cholula has a great feel come vist

394861455.name: Wear your tennis shoes!
394861455.author: a TripAdvisor user
394861455.reviewBody: Didn\'t have a whole lot of time here but when we arrived there were some local Indians doing a "goodbye to the sun" dance, it was pretty cool to watch, I then, got a blessing from them via smoke, very cool.  Then with my guide Jorge Mendoza (see review in Mexico Forum) hiked up the steep hill (rather than climb the stairs) you can do either or....and got to the top, great view.  The pyramid is very impressive, it\'s the largest pyramid in the world today, I have seen the ones in Egypt and this one is different, can\'t say don\'t see one over the other but this one has more to offer....from a distance it looks like a hill with a church on top but it is so much more than that, next time we go, I am going to go with enough time to go through the tunnels.  although the trek up the hill isn\'t easy, (altitude) the air seems very thin, it was difficult to catch my breath (actually, probably just out of shape)....but it was doable.  Lots of vendors down at the bottom with great Talavera and other local items and food for sale.  Loved it, just wish I had more time to spend here.  Lost my eye glasses diving out of the car to get some photos of the Indians dancing...please "pm" me if you happen to find them ...LOL

394486215.name: Nice Historical Locale
394486215.author: a TripAdvisor user
394486215.reviewBody: My family and I paid to trek through the tunnels of this pyramid during our visit to Cholula. This was an affordable little tour for the whole family. There is not much in the way of tour guides or teaching, but there is plenty to look at. We marveled at the ingenuity of the ancient architecture. Great History Lesson!

392512841.name: Visit on Sunday
392512841.author: a TripAdvisor user
392512841.reviewBody: Definitely a worthwhile side trip from Puebla. The tunnels under the pyramid are kinda neat. Be sure to visit on a Sunday, when Cholula is most alive. Plus, the archaeological site is free on Sundays, which saves a few pesos.

392335072.name: Amazing and impressive
392335072.author: a TripAdvisor user
392335072.reviewBody:
The size of this site is impressive.  First you walk through a 1200 foot long tunnel through the pyramid (you may want to rethink doing this if you are at all claustrophobic - usually I'm not but the tunnel did get to me a big) then you walk around various areas that the archeologists have uncovered.

And then you can walk up to the church!

Wear good shoes, even if you skip the church you'll be walking a lot.

388443470.name: beautiful view of history plus amazing vistas of surrounding area.
388443470.author: a TripAdvisor user
388443470.reviewBody: Get there early so you can see the Popo volcano before the day\'s haze and clouds roll in. Very historic and beautiful.

387947164.name: Great visit - but not for those with even mild claustrophobia!
387947164.author: a TripAdvisor user
387947164.reviewBody: This is a great archaeological site, primarily because archaeologists have dug tunnels into the interior of the solid-mass pyramid so that you can see the actual walls of the old pyramids over which the final pyramid was constructed.  It\'s fascinating!  However, if you have any type of claustrophobia, do not attempt the tunnels. They are never tight, but are never more than 1-2 body widths wide.  They are well lit but the sound is muffled and the further you go in, the more moist and still the air gets.  Groups can end up in front of you and behind you, leaving you feeling cramped with no place to retreat. I enjoyed the adventure very much, but at one point felt a bit uneasy for the first time in my life.

385697245.name: Worth the trip and in a cute little Mexican town
385697245.author: a TripAdvisor user
385697245.reviewBody: This is apparently the largest pyramid in the world. The pyramid is in the center of town with a colonial-style church at the top. The surrounding area of the pyramid is the cutest, most quaint little Mexican town. I loved that it wasn\'t a huge tourist trap. Felt authentically Mexican. Very few non-Mexican tourists. Lots of great shopping and restaurants in the surrounding areas. Would definitely recommend as a day trip from Puebla! But I would like to go back and stay in some of the cute hotels in the town.

384737025.name: Fun market, pyramid OK, didn\'t explore town much
384737025.author: a TripAdvisor user
384737025.reviewBody: A short taxi ride from downtown Puebla, and easy to pick up a bus for the return. We didn\'t get to the associated museum, the pyramid itself is huge but largely built over, with a gaudy church on top. Cacaxtla is quieter and truly impressive, but hard to get to unless you have a car.

376466766.name: Awesome place to visit
376466766.author: a TripAdvisor user
376466766.reviewBody: Easy to get to from anywhere in Puebla. Only took us about 30 minutes from the zocalo. Inside the pyramid is cool and the exposed remains outside are spectacular. The church on top is also worth climbing to. Make sure to go all the way around to get to the biggest pyramid.

374970399.name: The largest pyramid on Earth
374970399.author: a TripAdvisor user
374970399.reviewBody: It does not look like it because it is still covered by centuries of grass, but it is the largest pyramid on Earth on top of which the conquistadores put a lovely pink church. I recommend a visit of the excavation side where you can realize how big the pyramid was, we did go through the tunnel that goes under the pyramid but frankly I got claustrophobic and was keen to leave it asap. We then did climg to the top to see the little church (cute in itself) and the gorgeous vista. The volcanoes (el Popo and its sisters) are in the back yet as close as some pictures make you believe they are.\nDo not miss if you are in the region.

374954973.name: It worth the visit
374954973.author: a TripAdvisor user
374954973.reviewBody: The Pyramid of Cholula, is largest pyramid in the world with 400 meters per side. The visit could be just the pyramid or include the church at the top, by the end of the tour inside the pyramid.\nI strongly suggest that you use a guide for the tour of the pyramid, in order the get a good explanation about the different ages, and how the pyramids were constructed one above the other.

374924320.name: If you are at all claustrophobic, skip the tunnels
374924320.author: a TripAdvisor user
374924320.reviewBody: This archaeological site is home (currently) to the third largest temple in Mexico topped by a church.  There are 8 km of tunnels through the interior and you can walk through some 80 m.  We found the site in general interesting and worth a visit, but the tunnels were not very interesting and quite uncomfortable with tight spaces and loud tour groups ahead of and behind us.  Next time, we would definitely skip this part.  The site musuem is nice.

374281876.name: Mexico\'s mestizo heritage in a building...
374281876.author: a TripAdvisor user
374281876.reviewBody:
Historians say most of the spanish colonial religious buildings were built over the old indigenous ones as a way to make a point as conquerors and impose their religion. 

The pyramid of Cholula is where you can actually see this and understand a little bit more of the interesting mexican history.

Plus it has superb views of the surrounding volcanoes and it is a fun adventure to explore the excavations (not for claustrophobics).

Do not miss the views of the abadonned psychiatric hospital right next to the pyramid. Nothing to do with the pyramid, but it is interesting as it looks like the set of a horror movie.

374028131.name: Buena vista
374028131.author: a TripAdvisor user
374028131.reviewBody: This is perhaps one of my favourite places in the world. I\'ve been coming to Cholua for many years and never tire of the steep hike to the church on top of the pyramid or the stunning,  and ever changing,  views of Cholua and Puebla from the submit. \n\nThe availability of magnums and fiests at the top is a bonus especially for little ones or those with a sweet tooth.

370383159.name: Grander than the Grand Pyramid
370383159.author: a TripAdvisor user
370383159.reviewBody: They say the Great Pyramid of Cholula is bigger and taller than anything Egypt has to offer.Certainly it looks like a minimountain set on a fertile p[lain- and the climb to the top is not for the fainthearted. Much if it is still clad in the earth and debris of centuries, so the original stonework can only be glimpsed here and there. If you want closer contact there is a system of tunnels, carved by archeologists which lead through excavations of the pyramid\'s flanks. Steps drop waway or rise magestically under the earth shell. And don\'t m,iss the surroubnding church\'s (including the one on the toop) the gold leaf is dazzling.

368558352.name: Amazing historic place
368558352.author: a TripAdvisor user
368558352.reviewBody: We went to Cholula for the first time and was exactly when Popocateptl was making a little eruption so we had Ash Rain. Was interesting and fun. Besides that the pyramid is an incredible place that is being almost untouched. Highly recommended safe and fun if you are looking for History and Culture.

367263422.name: Your moment of Indiana Jones
367263422.author: a TripAdvisor user
367263422.reviewBody: This is the largest pre-industrial monument in the world, by volume, Atlanta.  Although it appears to be merely a hill with a church on top, don\'t be mislled.  The entrance is on the north side: buy your tickets, but before entering visit the fine little museum across the street.  Your tour of the pyramid itself starts with a trip through a portion of the 8 km of tunnels dug out by archaeologists to study how the structure was built (successively, in layers, over centuries).  This is not a good place for the claustriphobic!  When you emerge into the suddenly very bright courtyard, you can then visit the north side of the pyramid, which has been excavated and restored.  The is good signage in Spanish! English, and Nahuatl.  A visit should take you 60-90 minutes.  To the north of the site, by the exit, you\'ll find vendors, food, and snacks.  Also watch for the traditional Voladores from Veracruz, who perform their stately but risky spiral descent from a near by pole.  Totally worth the trip from Puebla to see!

361773046.name: Incredible! Do NOT miss this one!
361773046.author: a TripAdvisor user
361773046.reviewBody: The story to this pyramid is amazing! I will not say anything more as not to ruin it for you! Be sure to visit and a guide is helpful in order to learn the history. This is not the same as Teotihuacan, visit both!

361587475.name: Fantastic site
361587475.author: a TripAdvisor user
361587475.reviewBody: Though not as large as others, the site houses some great frescoes and has an attractive grounds.  A great day out from the traffic and smog of Mexico City.

360216807.name: be sure to use some sunscreen
360216807.author: a TripAdvisor user
360216807.reviewBody: Is a great place, if you go straight to the top you will find the awesome church of "la virgen de los remedios" with is above of one of the 2nd Largest pyramid in the world, you will find an awesome view from the volcano "Popocatepetl" and "Izztazihuatl", also the "Malinche" if you going down you must go have a PULQUE (traditional fermented drink"

359114377.name: 2nd largest pyramid in the World
359114377.author: a TripAdvisor user
359114377.reviewBody: Tip: be sure to pass through the tiny entrance of the pyramid! Also you can pay for a guide at the entrance to get much more information about the monument

357611600.name: Great Views
357611600.author: a TripAdvisor user
357611600.reviewBody: The combination of a church on top of a pyramid is really neat. It is a climb to get to the top, but just the views of Puebla and the volcanoes from the top make it worth it. The church is still active, so you can\'t take pictures and must be respectful inside. You can also view (but not walk through) some of the excavated ruins. It doesn\'t take long and I recommend it.

357469026.name: Great visit!
357469026.author: a TripAdvisor user
357469026.reviewBody: This is a must if you ever go to Puebla, this pyramid is the biggest pyramid in the world and the stories around it and how it was built and why are just awesome, make sure you hire a tour guide outside, they give you a tour and tell you all sorts of things from the culture and folklore and of course the history of the site.

348009221.name: Nice views.
348009221.author: a TripAdvisor user
348009221.reviewBody: The church that was built on top of the pyramid was lovely. And, it provides an amazing panoramic view of the city. The pyramids have not been restored to their former glory. But, the tunnels the archeologists dug in the 1930s were pretty cool.

345714510.name: Not the most stunning historic site but just sufficiently amazing to blow your mind
345714510.author: a TripAdvisor user
345714510.reviewBody:
We did not use a guide and left the museum to the end. Except for a fleeting glimpse of a school class we had the site to ourselves. 
Starting with the tunnel under the whole site was both stunning and enlightening. I can imagine the excitement as the archeologists painstakingly dug into the hill and found new foundations, rooms or wall. 
When you come out of the tunnel you need to turn right down the public path for about 200 m. You.m are outside the ruin's grounds and need to present your ticket to go through the turnstiles at a small building when the path ends in a T. Now the fun begins. The site is almost a three dimensional jigsaw puzzle, with layer on layer of changes made by each generation over a 900 year span. There are Spanish and English signage with quite reasonable explanations. As in most sites in the region there is only a fraction that has been excavated and restored. And of course at any time you can look up to the church on the top, another very pleasant view. 
The museum has a very nice, small but informative, collection of artifacts and a larges scale model of the site. Don't miss it, you find it across the street and down a 100 m from the site/tunnel entrance.

343185197.name: Largest Pyramid
343185197.author: a TripAdvisor user
343185197.reviewBody: Being the largest Pyramid in volume on the world, it is very interesting to realize that the Spanish took many of its rocks to build quite a number of the surrounding Churches. You should visit the inside to understand the various periods of construction started at about 300 bC. \nOn its top in 1594 was built the Church of Our Lady of Los Remedios.

342941719.name: very interesting but a bit lacking
342941719.author: a TripAdvisor user
342941719.reviewBody: i am a history buff.  have been to many mayan and aztec ruins.  this one is immense but honestly not a lot to see.  there is one side with a courtyard and some walls but most of it is unexcavated.   you can go thru the tunnel they carved out of the temple, and come into the courtyards, walls but not a lot to see.  amazing construction for sure, very detailed builders, herringbone designed bricks which is much more elaborate than most of the temples which makes it interesting.  there is a church on the top, gaudy, opulent and out of place on a pagan temple but there you go.  overall i would go to the mexico city ruins first as they are more elaborately displayed.  the market around this huge temple is interesting and don\'t miss the tall post with people circling it on ropes, amazing skill and coordination.

341791731.name: Worth a visit
341791731.author: a TripAdvisor user
341791731.reviewBody: The taxi getting there was the issue, they tried charging us 130$. Understood it should be 100$ or less. On the way back we luckily fell on the bus, which dropped us in town. The pyramid has not been fully escavated or restored which made it an awe.

341671401.name: Buried, but magnificent
341671401.author: a TripAdvisor user
341671401.reviewBody:
The great pyramid of Cholula is the largest monument ever built.  Anywhere.  Yes, I know, it just looks like a big hill, but don't blame the conquistadores—it was evidently already overgrown by the time they got there. At that time, Cholula — possibly the oldest continuously-inhabited city in the new world — was as bigger than any city in Spain.  It's still worth a visit.  Get your tickets in the booth on the north side, but before entering the tunnel, go across the street to the small but informative museum.  Then head into the tunnels. 

These were excavated in the last century by various archaeologists.  You can get a sense of how this enormous structure was built over various centuries.  

Upon emerging from the tunnel, you stroll through much of the southern face of the pyramid, which has been partially reconstructed.  You need some imagination, but you Han get a good sense of what this was all like.  Lots of good things to eat and (at times) quality souvenirs to be had.  I know some are disappointed that it hasn't been Disneyficado for the tourists, but to my mind is absolutely worth 2-3 hours.  It is worth hiring a guide.  They're infromative, and not expensive.

340582593.name: Nice place to visit
340582593.author: a TripAdvisor user
340582593.reviewBody: Interesting place. Catacombs, church on the top of what once was one of the greatest pyramids in the world.\nDon\'t forget to visit Museo de Sitio nearby.

339865290.name: Go with a guide
339865290.author: a TripAdvisor user
339865290.reviewBody: Interesting visit as our guide was able to explain the history and features of this large archeological site. You can visit the museum, inside of the pyramid, outer area with altars etc and then climb up to the Spanish church built on top of the pyramid which has great views over Puebla.

339261951.name: Slightly  disappointed
339261951.author: a TripAdvisor user
339261951.reviewBody: Easy trip from Puebla. A little  walk. But the great Pyramid  is just a big mound of dirt with a church on top. Some restoration  has started but not in the league of Coba, Ek Balam ,  Palenque  etc. Its free. Got to the top and clouds blocked  popacatepal . Interesting  town. But not all that, unless you want to party.

337334359.name: Biggest pyramid that cannot be seen
337334359.author: a TripAdvisor user
337334359.reviewBody: The pyramid is bigger than the great Sun and Moon Pyramids of Teotihuacan but unfortunately it is under a great deal of dirt. Some of the building blocks of the pyramid were used to build the church atop the pyramid. The church itself is lavish and pretty though it does not allow any photographs. There\'s no place on the top to eat a meal, but you can get snacks. The views of the volcano were wonderful

336534129.name: Big pyramids but still buried
336534129.author: a TripAdvisor user
336534129.reviewBody: I visited Cholula 15 years ago and I found it to be exactly the same. The pyramids are very very big but are still buried. The visit is going through the tunnels and then you see a part of the pyramids. Do not miss taking a picture of the church on top and of the two volcanoes. I recommend going early because it gets foggy later in the day.

330542790.name: Allow plenty of time!
330542790.author: a TripAdvisor user
330542790.reviewBody: Very historically interesting!  This site includes ancient pyramids dwellings with a Catholic Church built on top.  The hike to the church is not easy, but definitely worth the effort...the views of Cholula and Puebla are magnificent and it\'s also fun to see the active volcano, Popo.

329942670.name: Walk INSIDE of the Pyramid.
329942670.author: a TripAdvisor user
329942670.reviewBody: This is definitely worth the trip. This is only about 20 min from Puebla and should not be missed. Our Guide Filiberto was wonderful and full of knowledge about this and the town. We had a great time!

329395966.name: Great view - Take the underground walk
329395966.author: a TripAdvisor user
329395966.reviewBody: This is a rather expansive area. In addition to the walk up to the top, where the church is, there is an underground walk through the pyramid, still being excavated to some extent. The entrance is on the street, off to the left side of the pyramid. The exit is in the rear of the pyramid, where there are numerous excavated parts of the pyramid, with signage explaining each, etc. You can spend a few hours exploring.\n

321265455.name: Building a church on a pyramid? Come on.
321265455.author: a TripAdvisor user
321265455.reviewBody: The place is inspiring, but we really did not get the pyramid. The museum or any other place around did not provide the answer how to click all the eras together and how the pyramid actually works under all the vegatation and the church.

313564200.name: Very historical and very interesting ... particularly because it is partially buried with a Catholic Church on top!
313564200.author: a TripAdvisor user
313564200.reviewBody: Very historical and very interesting ... particularly because it is partially buried with a Catholic Church on top!\n\nWhat a Conquest!

310349117.name: Inside and up
310349117.author: a TripAdvisor user
310349117.reviewBody: I visited with an organized tour group. We stopped at the museum first to see a model of the Great Pyramid of Cholula and Our Lady of Remedies church. Then we went inside the pyramid. It was a short walk along narrow passageways on metal grates. The path was even and well lit. There were no murals or artifacts. It was disappointing to see graffiti by the exit doorway. Outside the pyramid, the excavated ruins proved to be more fascinating and interesting. There is ample signage in Spanish and English. The staircase of only one side of the pyramid has been restored and people are allowed to climb up at their own risk. There are rope handles on either side if you\'re not comfortable climbing unaided. The views of Cholula from the top of the staircase are nice but not spectacular.  If you\'re in the Puebla area, this is a worthwhile place to visit.

310261764.name: Unique way to experience history
310261764.author: a TripAdvisor user
310261764.reviewBody: The visit to the pyramid in Cholula takes some time, as you should first visit the museum that details the history and design/building of the pyramid. The admission to the museum is covered in your ticket price to enter the pyramid and is just across the street from the ticket booth. After the museum, you will then enter the pyramid and wind your way through km\'s of tunnels. There are some arms of the pathway that branch off to allow you to see up and down staircases. Take your time walking through the tunnels and imagine all the work that went into building this great pyramid. You will eventually emerge out on the other side (be aware, your eyes may need a few minutes to adjust to the sunlight again after being underground for a while). You can then walk up the side of the pyramid to the top where the Church of Our Lady Remedies is located (and regular services still take place). It really makes you think and understand the motives/actions of the church on traditional indigenous practices of not only when the area was conquered but what still goes on today. You also get a great view of Cholula, Puebla, and Popocat\u00e9petl volcano from here.

308736302.name: Fascinating site with layers of history in Cholula - 30 mins outside of Puebla
308736302.author: a TripAdvisor user
308736302.reviewBody: This is really a fascinating site in Cholula - 30 mins outside of Puebla. The pyramid was covered in volcanic ash and then foilage until it appreared to be a hill. The spanish came and built a church on top. It is now partially excavated and there is a small, simple museum at the base with more information. The walk up top in nice and the views are spectacular. It is almost immediately next to the Cholula town square and when I visited on a Sunday was surrounded by a wonderful, crowded market. Lovely day trip from Puebla (can certainly be done in a few hours if you\'re in a rush).

306110274.name: The Views are Spectacular
306110274.author: a TripAdvisor user
306110274.reviewBody: The view from the top, at the church, is amazing.  In the backdrop you have the volcano Popo in all its glory.  We actually got a picture of it erupting a plumb of smoke while taking a picture of my mom.  This is, I believe, the largest pyramid in the world in terms of mass.  It is quite a steep climb  but well worth it.  Hey, my mom did it when she was 87...and without a problem!

292386919.name: Unfortunately, you will not see the pyramid!
292386919.author: a TripAdvisor user
292386919.reviewBody: Apparently, this pyramid is an amazing creation. But the problem is you can\'t see it. You can only see a hill with a church on top, and the great pyramid is underneath... There is not-so-long tunnel inside, which is not very helpful to sense the grandeur of the pyramid. The entrance was free on Sunday when I went to Cholula. I climbed up the hill, enjoyed the views and went down. Surrounding the foot of the hill were numerous stalls with local handicraft and products, including fried insects (grasshoppers etc.) which I\'ve found very good with beer.\n\nConclusion: if you consider going to Cholula and Puebla, give priority to Puebla!

291289938.name: A must-see
291289938.author: a TripAdvisor user
291289938.reviewBody: I will never understand how this could ever happen: a Catholic Church was built on a pyramids. This is part of Mexican history and worth to go there and see it with your own eyes.\n\nA wonderful view from above of the city Cholula. The pyramid is a 3 minutes walk away to the center of the city.

290563773.name: Not sure i would recommend that visit
290563773.author: a TripAdvisor user
290563773.reviewBody:
Honestly i am not sure it is worth the visit ; with the Mxp 52  ticket you get access to 
- the tunnel inside the pyramid : not especially interesting , these are modern tunnels caved by archeologist , no artefacts , no paintings to be seen .
-The small museum with a scale model of the archeological zone and a few objects from the pyramid . Nice but very , very simple if compared with the Plaza mayor museum in Mexico city  
- a vist to the zone of the altars , impressive by its size but again no paintings , no artefacts , a few big stones ..
I have a feeling a good walk on both  sides of the  hill which covers the pyramid gives you almost the same benefits plus a fantastic view ,for free and open anytime

289380402.name: The great pyramid Tlachihualtepetl
289380402.author: a TripAdvisor user
289380402.reviewBody: one of the largest pyramids in the world, as to foundation, a city inhabited from 100 BC, atop the church of remedies, and where paints a mural of the drinkers of pulque, a fermented drink of maguey .\nhere in cholula we find the mural of the pulque drinkers made between 50 and one hundred years a.d. prehispanic time. only the priests & elders were allowed to drink pulque , and if anyone  broke this rule they were severly punished.\n legend says that  queen xochitl mayahuel   while  walking saw a rabbit, sipping water  from a maguey , caught and cooked him and  liked the taste. she  returned and took the honey water, not only honey water   but also the leaves of the maguey was used as roofing  for houses,  paper is made from it for codices , fibers for threads & twine, its sap is used as medicine for some bites,  the maguey is currently used as a fence and to prevent erosion..

286600555.name: Go if you are around, not a must in life.
286600555.author: a TripAdvisor user
286600555.reviewBody: Truly unnecessary, not that great, not quite a pyramid. Poblanos may hate me for this, but it\'s not worth it. On the bright side, restaurants and most of The food around the pyramid is awesome!

281757283.name: Amazing old and new worlds
281757283.author: a TripAdvisor user
281757283.reviewBody: It is a real shame that the Spanish tried to obliterate the native culture, burying a pyramid and then building a church on top!  It has meant that there is plenty to see here though.  The excavations around one side of the pyramid and the open tunnels give a great insight into the local inhabitants before the Spanish, not Inca or Myan.  the Church at the top would be worthy of a visit in its own right, with commanding views of Cholula and surrounds.

278600618.name: Good place to visit
278600618.author: a TripAdvisor user
278600618.reviewBody: We visited here with three small kids.  The place was full of families and very interesting.  We would recommend it to families.

277395125.name: Good if you are into history, but not much of a sight
277395125.author: a TripAdvisor user
277395125.reviewBody: Arguably one of the, if not the, biggest pyramid in the world. Unfortunately it\'s covered with earth and has a church on top. You can walk through a tunnel-system underneath it, but there\'s not much to see. Outside you can take a look at a few ruins, but they are not very impressive. I guess you need to read a lot about the place to really be able to enjoy it to some extend. That said, the town of Cholula is good for a stroll.

275632793.name: Church Trumps Pyramid
275632793.author: a TripAdvisor user
275632793.reviewBody: This is an interesting day trip from Mexico City.  There is a lovely Catholic Church built on top of an Aztec Pyramid.  Our guide said the pyramid was covered over with volcanic matter and when the people built the church, they simply thought they were building it on top of a small mountain.  Later it was discovered the mountain was actually a pyramid.  Part of the pyramid has been uncovered and part is a reconstruction.  To get to the church, you have to climb a pretty good ways and you will be rewarded by 360 degree vistas of nearby Puebla and Cholula.  On a clear day you will be able to see the nearby volcano.  The church is very pretty inside.  Highly recommend this day trip

273699021.name: Fascinating
273699021.author: a TripAdvisor user
273699021.reviewBody: A must-see whilst in Puebla. Fascinating site, especially when entering the site via the tunnels. Such a shame that most of the pyramid is covered by the hill, but you can get a good appreciation of the scale of the site when exploring the tunnels. Make sure you have a few hours to spare to explore everything, including climbing up to the church at the top. Wonderful view from the top to get some good photos. Extra bonus if you are there when the local Indians are performing their dance at the back of the archaeological site. 52 pesos well spent to gain entry.

272580707.name: Little bit disappointed
272580707.author: a TripAdvisor user
272580707.reviewBody: We took a direct bus from Puebla to Cholula (very cheap 15pesos round trip). Obviously we did not take the one that goes directly near the archeological area. Anyway it gave us the opportunity to walk a little bit alongside the Zocalo (very cute), the traditional market (should take a look) and shops. The archeological area includes a very small museum (with prehispanic poteries), the tunnels under the Great Pyramid and the remainings of the Pyramid and surroundings. The Great Pyramid is not very impressive as most of it is located under a hill. The site is well documented (english and spanish).

271039484.name: One of the true wonders of the world, still obscured
271039484.author: a TripAdvisor user
271039484.reviewBody: The world\'s largest pyramid is a must-see. Well, actually you can\'t see it, just some structures at its bottom as well as 800m out of 8km of corridors inside. Nevertheless, you can imagine how grand it has to be, given that the Spaniards build a church on top of it.  I would love to see the pyramid in its full shape, at least from one side...

270970770.name: The Great Pyramid of Cholula
270970770.author: a TripAdvisor user
270970770.reviewBody: Although the Great Pyramid today looks like just another hill it is an entirely man made construction. The tunnels into it show the different phases of construction and the museum of the site just in front of the entrance to the tunnels shows the history of excavations in the pyramid. This is a site well worth seeing!

268378746.name: Very unexplored.
268378746.author: a TripAdvisor user
268378746.reviewBody: It is said has been explored only 1%.  8 kms (5 miles) of tunnels, very impressive.  What has been explored in interesting, but others archeological sites like Teotihuacan or Chichen Itza to name a few are better option.  Nice to climb to the Church, which is very nice.  But no pictures are allowed in most of the churchs in Cholula.  There are 365 churchs in this town, one for evrey day in the year.  History says that when the Spaniards found this place there were 400 temples, so the Spanish Crown ordered to build a church in eacho of those.

266534901.name: Cholula, one of the oldest market structures in Old Mesoamerica
266534901.author: a TripAdvisor user
266534901.reviewBody: If you plan to go, read a little before hand! Cholula is interesting if you see it as it was during its past glories. Imagine all those people buying and selling their stuf... amazing!

261009819.name: Must be visited
261009819.author: a TripAdvisor user
261009819.reviewBody: an amazing way to understand how the ancient inhabitants of this valley built this largest Pyramid, and the guide I had was the oldest in the location, I spent two hours with him...excellent, must be seen

260763795.name: Great pyramid scene and more
260763795.author: a TripAdvisor user
260763795.reviewBody: We arrived to Cholula Pyramid from   Puebla Capu bus station. After taking a taxi from the terminal (120 Mexican pesos). It was a beautiful picture of the church on top of the mountain and Pyramid at the bottom. We did not do the tunnels or climb to the cathedral. If you plan to do it estimate at least 3 hours. It\'s not an easy way up and takes time. There is a variety of local souvenirs shops as well as small bars and restaurant around the area. Please visit this place is a different taste of Mexico.\n

257919394.name: Hoped to see more
257919394.author: a TripAdvisor user
257919394.reviewBody: You can go inside the pyramid, but there\'s not a lot to see and you won\'t need the guide. At the exit an archeological parc awaits you - extra money. It\'s interesting, but go when the indians are showing their dance. MUST: go up to the pyramid, the church is wonderful and you have a superb view of Puebla and the Popocatepetl. Try the food they propose you on the way, there\'s a market too and the center of Cholula is not far away.

257577976.name: Awesome
257577976.author: a TripAdvisor user
257577976.reviewBody: I was not expecting another archeological site after a month in the Yucatan.  The dimensions are larger than the Great Pyramid in Egypt.  Unfortunately. The Spanish demolished a lot of it.  But what is left is fabulous.  There is a tunnel through the pyramid you can walk through.

256990903.name: Interesting
256990903.author: a TripAdvisor user
256990903.reviewBody: Loved having this so close. Not nearly as claustrophobic as I expected, but I would have had problems if it were more crowded. Be sure to visit the museum across the way, too.

255785722.name: Cholula tour
255785722.author: a TripAdvisor user
255785722.reviewBody: Went inside the pyramid as part of this tour.  Also experienced fried grasshoppers (tasty!) sold as a snack.  Got an excellent historical, cultural, religious overview from our tour guide, Galo Velazquez Martinez of Tours Puebla.  Also saw the two churches on the way \nback.  This tour is worth a whole day.   Can highly recommend our guide, excellent English.  Can find Tours Puebla in the tourist information center on the north side of the Puebla zocalo.

253392524.name: Pyramid
253392524.author: a TripAdvisor user
253392524.reviewBody: It\'s really too bad that there is a Catholic Church on top of this wonderful pyramid .It really shows the arrogance of the conquering race . The sales carts at the foot of the Pyramid were off putting BUT it still is a MUST see.

250097792.name: Worth a visit -
250097792.author: a TripAdvisor user
250097792.reviewBody: Given that this is a very interesting archeological site with an Aztec pyramid that is the largest ever built. Be prepared however to only be able to see some of the pyramid structure as it was only partially uncovered -  it is still worth a visit. You can walk through a long tunnel and see where multiple underground stairs and tunnels have been built underneath the mountain. There is only one full section of the pyramid that you can walk up. Alternatively you can go up a winding path to the catholic church on top of the hill. From here there is a 360 degree view of Cholula and its many churches. There is a charge for entry (about US$6 ) and it is a taxi ride from Puebla - about 30mins- but taxis are readily available in both directions and fairly cheap.

247014470.name: Unusual, a do not miss
247014470.author: a TripAdvisor user
247014470.reviewBody: We almost skipped this visit, but are so glade we went. You enter through a long set of old tunnels through the mountain & come out at the base of a nice climb to a chapel and then the church on top of the hill. Lots of vendors outside the entrance and a nice little park.

246616889.name: Well worth the visit
246616889.author: a TripAdvisor user
246616889.reviewBody: Go out of your way to visit the Great Pyramid of Cholula. Teotihuac\u00e1n is fantastic of course, but the experience of walking through the inside of the Cholula pyramid will make you feel like a real life Indiana Jones.

244733833.name: A must visit for those interested in archaeology.
244733833.author: a TripAdvisor user
244733833.reviewBody: When measured by volume this is the biggest pyramid ever built - bigger than the great pyramid of Egypt.  It is also one of the biggest buildings (by volume) ever constructed in the history of the earth.  As it is covered by a hill you cn only appreciate the size by walking through the tunnel system below.  This is not for the claustrophobic.  It is well worth the price to hire a guide so you can have a better understanding of what is buried under the hill.  by all means stop by the nearby museum (the entrance ticket to the pyramid includes the museum.)

244420496.name: A huge Pyramid
244420496.author: a TripAdvisor user
244420496.reviewBody: The Cholula pyramid is well worth a visit. You can climb the road leading to the top to visit the church built by the conquistadores, or you can walk through the long tunnel that traverses the base of this mammoth structure. You\'ll be greatly impressed by the human audacity that allowed such a massive project to be undertaken.  Cholula is of considerable interest to those wishing to learn more about the early days of the conquest. A lot of human drama played out here as two dissimilar cultures collided violently.

241160378.name: Not so much to see
241160378.author: a TripAdvisor user
241160378.reviewBody:
The Great Pyramid of Cholula don't really count to one of my favorite in Mexico. For sure there are better places to go (like Teotihuacán, Monte Albán, Palenque, Tulum, Chichen-Itza, ..).

I went to this pyramid with a friend on our three weeks trip through Mexico by taxi from Puebla. It happened exactly what I read before in other reviews, the staff at the entrance to the pyramid's tunnel system is unfriendly and tells you they don't have change in hope they can keep it. Fortunately some other visitors behind us could help us, and you could see the stuff didn't like that. The price is too high anyway, the tunnel system is basically just one long small boring tunnel. You cannot go any side-way. Going up to the church (you don't need to pay if you just go up to the church), it is nice there and you also have a nice look on the surrounding area. Unfortunately the people upstairs were not really friendly neither and I had the feeling people don't like much that tourists visit that church.

Well, in sum, if you are just a short time in Puebla I would recommend you to rather see more of that beautiful city.

240883064.name: Great visit
240883064.author: a TripAdvisor user
240883064.reviewBody: The red and white bus will drop you off in front of the site for about 7 pesos.  A collectivo will drop you in the city and a 15 minute walk to the site.  Make sure you go through the tunnel.\nThere are actually 5 pyramids nested within each other.  A guide would help explain and fill in the details and history. \nIt is not as spectacular as Teotihaucan,  but it is amazing that this was once and area to 100,000 inhabitants.

239830502.name: Glad I Visited Here
239830502.author: a TripAdvisor user
239830502.reviewBody: From the tourist info, I knew that this was a huge pyramid that was not excavated. Sounds cool, right? But then I found out about the tunnel system that was excavated in the 1930s and suddenly this became much more exciting. The archeologists carved out tunnels that exposed some of the stone facing of the original pyramid. So while you can\'t walk up those steps, you can see parts of them to get a sense of just how large this pyramid was. There is also a large partially excavated area not under the pyramid that shows many sets of stairs, altars, etc. Don\'t miss out on walking to the church at the top, it\'s an amazing view. That part is free, you pay to access the tunnels and ruins.

239719678.name: Cholula is a must when visting Mexico City
239719678.author: a TripAdvisor user
239719678.reviewBody: I went to Mexico City for a long weekend to check it out, as I had never been there. A friend I met there was heading to Puebla/Cholula and asked me to join. I\'m very glad I did! It was the best part of my time in Mexico City and the small town is just magnificent. Loaded with colonial architecture and colors you expect to see based on art and guidebook photos, this place will not let you down. We had a great meal around the main square of Cholula, which had a market and other festivities (this was on a Sunday). Meanwhile, the pyramid is a short walk from the main square and is just amazing! For never having heard of it before, I did not expect such a large pyramid! In fact, I was told it was the largest pyramid in the New World! You can enter into it\'s labrynth of tunnels under the earth and wonder about it\'s surrounding grounds. \n\nTake the bus from the main station in Mexico City to Puebla (1.5 hours). From Puebla you can get a collectivo van for a few pesos to Cholula. (20 min)

238616868.name: Easy day trip by bus from Puebla
238616868.author: a TripAdvisor user
238616868.reviewBody:
To get to Cholula from Puebla I got a local bus. It was very easy even if you don't speak Spanish. The buses leave from 6 Poniente between 11 and 13 Norte. It was marked clearly on the tourist map. The bus itself has 'Cholula' written on the windscreen. The fare was 7.50pesos each way and dropped off at the entry to the pyramids. You can't miss it. (But if you can... ask the driver)

You can walk up to the top to the cathedral to get an amazing view of the volcano and Cholula. You can access this without paying the admission fee.

The ruins are quite unique as they have a cathedral built on top of them. The entry fee was 48 pesos.

After buying your ticket you can walk through the underground tunnels. They are probably around 3 feet wide and 6 feet high (but with an arched ceiling so tall people beware). It was a bit unpleasant to be in there with a crowd so time your entry to avoid a tour group. I managed to let a group pass and have the tunnels to myself.

After the tunnels you can walk around the ruins outside which is quite a nice view. There are some Spanish and English signs around though not especially informative. Guides are available for a fee. Up to you.

Cholula is also a nice town to walk around have lunch, shop, look at buildings etc.
 
To get back to Puebla the bus left from outside the pyramids again. Just make sure you get one that says 'Centro' to go to the centre of Puebla as some only go to the outer suburbs. Staff at the pyramid ticket both would help if you were stuck.

238487083.name: About 2 hs from Mexico city and it\u00b4s worth a visit
238487083.author: a TripAdvisor user
238487083.reviewBody: The best way to get to this pyramid from Mexico DF on a day trip is to take the bus Estrella Roja wich departs at 08:30 am from TAPO bus station, it will go direct to San Diego square, 2 miles from the pyramid but you can take a taxi or walk, ADO buses go only to Puebla CAPU bus station and you\u00b4ll have to take another bus to Cholula. The last bus back to Mexico is 04:30 pm and this on the way to Mexico passes by the street 12 poniente wich from the pyramid is closer than San Diego square. It\u00b4s not the Pyramid the only thing to see in San Pedro Cholula, the pueblo around the archaelocic zone is very beautiful and there are many shops to buy souvenirs and there\u00b4s always some festivals on sundays, I think sunday is a good day to go to Cholula, and the entrance is free. Check www.estrellaroja.com.mx to see the buses timetable.

237596162.name: Cool attraction
237596162.author: a TripAdvisor user
237596162.reviewBody: The inside of the pyramid is a small little maze with gates allowing you to see the other tunnels that were built. It feels a little spooky but cool to see the inside. After the tunnel, it is a relaxing walk around the ruins. We even brought a blanket and just chilled outside for a while. It is a nice leisurely attraction to see.

234025553.name: Corruption at the tickets!
234025553.author: a TripAdvisor user
234025553.reviewBody: The place is interesting to see but when you feel cheated out by the ticketing window when they tell everyone they don\'t have change to give back, it kinda bums you! always keep change with you when buying your tickets to enter the pyramid. Oh, and if you\'re claustrophobic, its not the best idea to enter the pyramid. but a memorable experience nonetheless.

231077456.name: Wonderful site to visit
231077456.author: a TripAdvisor user
231077456.reviewBody: Although it looks like a hill with a Colonial church on top, this is actually a series of pyramids built on top of each other. The tunnels make this site unique and are not for the claustrophobic.  The outside sites are well labeled and quite interesting and the small museum has a wonderful display of what the pyramid actually looked like before the Spanish conquest.  The church is lovely and the view fantastic.  I only wish the weather would have permitted us to see the volcano.

227123003.name: Great place
227123003.author: a TripAdvisor user
227123003.reviewBody: Very nice historic place, and cooI spots.  I recommend to take the guided tour.  For the outside be sure to have an antiallergic pill with you if you are allergic to bees.\nNot recommended for claustrophobic people.

226146691.name: A Grand Pyramid
226146691.author: a TripAdvisor user
226146691.reviewBody:
When reading some of the reviews, I have to wonder if some were written by folks visiting the same site?  Guides in Mexico can be loosely regulated and facts (creative storytelling) may vary a great deal.

One of the real treasures is the fairly small museo not far from the entrance to the pyramid.  Between the pyramid models and the pre-Hispanic pottery recovered from the site, a visit is well worth it!.

We didn't hire a professional guide but were fortunate enough to be guided by a highly recognized artist who lives on the border between Puebla and Cholula and also works for the State of Puebla Tourism Division.  He and his father are really into Mexico's history and are oriented towards carrying on their craft in a traditional manner.  According to his explanation, the pyramid was buried by the local people to hide it from the Spanish.  When one considers that this pyramid has the largest base area of any pyramid in the world, one has to wonder if the pyramid construction or the process of burying was the greater engineering feat?

Well worth the time and effort to visit and learn about a huge element in Mexico's history!

224361630.name: Incredible Site for a family visit
224361630.author: a TripAdvisor user
224361630.reviewBody:
Great stop for a family.  Very reasonably priced.  We started off walking around the outside of the pyramid.  There were plaques scattered around written in both Spanish and English.  We also had copied the Wikipedia article for additional reading.  We then went to steps you can climb up (which overlook the town), followed by visiting the church that sits atop the pyramid.  I'd recommend anyone hit these stops.

We knew from our reading on line that there were tunnels you can go through under the pyramid but we did not know where they were so we started asking and were pointed in the right direction.  DO NOT MISS THE TUNNELS.  They were super cool to walk through and are included in the price of admission.

I'd highly recommend stopping at the Great Pyramid.

221784710.name: Significant pyramid
221784710.author: a TripAdvisor user
221784710.reviewBody: I was still really glad I visited Cholula , even though we visited it the day after teotihuacan . It is the largest of all the pyramids in its base and still only partly uncovered. The church on the top is beautiful and the views are well worth the walk to the top. My recommendation would be to hire a local guide when you buy your entry ticket to take you through the tunnel system , as it is a bit meaningless wandering thru on your own.

217906820.name: A historic place but not a tourist destination
217906820.author: a TripAdvisor user
217906820.reviewBody: We had heard good things about Cholula and the pyramid, but were disappointed with the whole experience. It is of course a great historic place, but it is not to interesting to visit in itself unless you have a great guide. It is a big hill with a beautiful church on top. We paid for entrance and were fascinated by  the tunnels inside the pyramid, but it too much money for very little. No signs or information and on The other side of the tunnels people were walking their dogs and we could have seen that for free if we had known. It is difficult to see much of The pyramid itself.

215776832.name: Loved the town of Cholula and the Pyramid
215776832.author: a TripAdvisor user
215776832.reviewBody:
We employed a guide for a nominal fee who went through the tunnels with us. He pointed out  spots that might go unnoticed, like the holes of the folk who tried to dig their way out! He also explained the drainage and water saving system that was so practical.
Our cell phones went pflooey with the "magnetic energy" and lots of other fascinating experiences. We took great pictures looking down tunnels that are great.

Don't miss the museum which explains why this is the largest pyramid by volume in the world! The volume goes DOWN and out, not up! I started to ask "Why?" to so many things that I saw and have not stopped yet. Every day I want to discover a little more about these ancient people.

The cathedral at the top is gorgeous. The town is friendly, easy parking and the zocolo(center square) is wonderfully interesting for lunches, dinners and coffees too. The weekends have events throughout the year.

212960808.name: A Must Visit If Interested in Pre-History and The Conquest
212960808.author: a TripAdvisor user
212960808.reviewBody: I have read some of the less than stellar reviews, but they did not keep me from visiting this site.  We opted to go there on our own and hire a guide, rather than use a tour bus.  The tourism office said that if you use a tour bus, you get an explanation while on the bus, and then are left on your own to explore.  My suggestion is to get there on your own, and hire a guide.  I used to attend ruins on my own, and then about ten years ago changed my tune, and now realize that a federally authorized and trained guide is the way to go.  All the guide books and signage at the site, are no match for having a guide explain everything to you.  You probably don\'t have unlimited time while in Puebla, so you have a choice. Use a tour bus, do a cursory tour on your own without a guide, or spend $20 or so and get a 50 minute explanation, with all your questions answered.  The vistas from the church atop the pyramids are remarkable, even during cloudy weather.  The tunnels, are impressive, for the parts which are original. Yes, there are pre-Hispanic ruins that are more impressive (i.e. in Mexico City, Monte Alb\u00e1n in Oaxaca, in the Yucat\u00e1n, and of course Machu Pichu), but for conquest and pre-History buffs, it\'s worth a visit.

206403210.name: A significant pyramid is all that is left.
206403210.author: a TripAdvisor user
206403210.reviewBody: Just seeing one of the worlds biggest pyramids is enough. There is nothing new to see beyond that. I found the tunnels a bit of a let down due to the very recent nature of them. The excavations at the foot of the pyramid are a bit confusing. It is hard to put it together in a context that makes you say " oh, this it what it all looked like". Signage is only relevant to someone with a technical background. Most of the IANH signs around sights in Mexico are. The museum was about 80 % pottery. Very little weaponry. No a balanced picture. The pyramid is real big.

203671574.name: One of the most awesome things I have ever seen
203671574.author: a TripAdvisor user
203671574.reviewBody: Very close to Puebla and a must see if you are in that area. The church on top is beautiful, the views are phenomenal, and the pyramids are also great. Underneath the pyramids are tunnels that are really cool to walk through. All around are little shops and other museums dedicated to this site. So glad I got to see this. It is very difficult to find directions to this or to get help from a GPS. Just go to Cholula and you will see the church on the hill. Also, signs in Cholula lead to the pyramide. Parking is very cheap and you may even find free parking. Also of note, if you pay for a ticket to the pyramids, everything is included (the other nearby museums dedicated to the site and the tunnels). It cost around $4 or $5 per person. When you get to the tunnels, you will be asked if you want to pay more for a tour guide. They aren\'t real pushy, but I don\'t think a guide is necessary unless you are alone and spooked out underneath there.

202635408.name: Interesting but requires guidance
202635408.author: a TripAdvisor user
202635408.reviewBody:
Whilst staying at Puebla, a few friends and I hired a taxi to Cholula to visit this site. We travelled early in the morning to avoid the heat of the day. 

When we arrived our first action was to climb to the top of the hill and see the church which is built over the pyramid, which largely remains uncovered. The hill is extremely steep and not for the feint hearted and it was a popular spot for joggers and dog walkers. 

The 360 view from the top is quite spectacular, though when I visited the view to the volcano was quite obscured due to the smoke and haze. It is an active volcano. The church itself in comparison to others visited, was quite modest, we did not linger as many were in prayer.

We then descended and made our way to the entrance of the pyramid. The entrance fee was 46 Pesos and this covered entrance into the pyramid tunnels which is within the hill and the surrounding grounds which has various excavation sites and lastly the museum. 

When we entered the tunnels we were in front of a group of local school children, so we felt quite hurried going through the maze of tunnels, though admittedly there is nothing to really see or read in there. For those who suffer claustrophobia, it may be a harrowing experience. I have to admit being 'pursued' by a group of excited children in such surroundings made me feel a little like Indiana Jones being chased by a large boulder! 

Upon exiting the tunnel, the teachers of the school group commenced a lesson, obviously about the site and unfortunately our Spanish was not sufficient to benefit from lingering to listen. 

We continued around the site, which is sprawled across large grounds. Although there is much to see in terms of excavations, there is actually little information available. There are stone tablets with both Spanish and English descriptions, however some were a little hard to read and it would have benefited with more information at times. 

At the end of this section, there is a large exposed section of the pyramid, which you can climb. The pyramid is expansive, which is evident by the size of the grounds and is reported to be the largest archaeological site of a pyramid in the new world.

After we exited this attraction, we tried to locate another site, however we couldn't locate it. It was a building made of sacrificed children's skulls. We then visited the museum, which was quite small but had a great 3D map of the pyramid and surrounds and gave us a great aerial perspective of what we had just visited. The museum also has a replica chamber of what was unearthed by archeologists when they were excavating the pyramid. The colours are quite vivid.

We took half a day to visit this attraction and recommend starting in the morning.
