It was quite interesting but when compared to others I subsequently visited on my trip through Mexico and Central America, I would suggest you find a local guide to obtain the best experience. I still enjoyed the visit nonetheless.

202506779.name: nice
202506779.author: a TripAdvisor user
202506779.reviewBody:
i visit this with a tour bus

i enjoyed a lot this experience

in cholula you can see better the mexican life and culture under of volcano shadow

i enjoy  alot

202498916.name: Needs Interpretation
202498916.author: a TripAdvisor user
202498916.reviewBody: Having visited a number of pre-Columbian ruins in the Mexico, Central and South America, I would say this is one you could skip--  unless you have hired a knowledgable guide. While I don\'t dispute that this is a significant site, it doesn\'t mean much without good interoperation. The signs at the excavated portions are not enough. The best part of this Cholula Pyramid was the Museum across there street from the entrance.

201938322.name: Very interesting
201938322.author: a TripAdvisor user
201938322.reviewBody:
We took a taxi from Historic Puebla to explore the pyramids of Cholula for the day. The taxi cost 130 pesos which seemed really cheap for about a 30 minute taxi ride. 

The entrance to the Pyramid takes you right through the center of the pyramid and was pretty cool to see. There are a lot of passages and stairs going in all directions which are unfortunately blocked off so you must stick to the main passage. Upon exiting the tunnel we climbed to the top of the Pyramid where there is a Catholic Church and great views out over the city. 

My favorite part of the trip was a section of the pyramid that had been completely excavated. Here you could climb up the stairs and really appreciate the grandeur of what was accomplished to build the pyramid. Most of the pyramid is still covered with dirt.

197182092.name: Early Morning or late afternoon
197182092.author: a TripAdvisor user
197182092.reviewBody: Climb the pyramid of Cholula in the morning or late afternoon. You\u00b4ll get awesome views of the Popocatepetl when the sun is behind it (afternoon, time depending on season).

196333946.name: Interesting
196333946.author: a TripAdvisor user
196333946.reviewBody: Tunnels are a little tight, lots of walking around the site.  A couple hours at the most.  Hard to imagine how big it really is.

195896091.name: Inside the pyramid
195896091.author: a TripAdvisor user
195896091.reviewBody: Not much to see from the outside because of decadence over time, but it is possible to walk the archeological tunnels inside to see the layers of construciton over time.

193078380.name: One of kind cultural experience
193078380.author: a TripAdvisor user
193078380.reviewBody: The tour begins with a passage inside the main pyramid. The tunnels are truly impressive, extensive, and enriching. The museum is great. We really enjoyed this part of our trip, definetly recommend it.

193006925.name: Large Ancient Site That Should Not Be Missed
193006925.author: a TripAdvisor user
193006925.reviewBody: The tunnels under the hillside are amazing as you pass through a maze of pathways dug deep in the earth. It is well lit and very comfortably cool on hot days. If you remain on ground level you will discover the ancient ruins of the great Cholula Pyramid that is without the hill covering. The site is actually quite large and has some very interesting formations as well as a large structure at the end of the trail with a great view from the top. If you wish to see the cathedral then take the pathway that takes you up from the tunnel exit to the top of the hill. The view is worth it and the church is quite pretty too. Interior photos of the church are not permitted but there is plenty to photograph on the outside. If you are lucky you might see the local spotted squirrels having a snack just over the walls of the pathway or even a brightly colored hummingbird gathering nectar from the flowers but even without the local fauna and flora the views are fantastic! On clear days you should see the volcano looming large in the distance!

192840200.name: The largest pyramid of the world where you can see the inside part of it
192840200.author: a TripAdvisor user
192840200.reviewBody: Good museum showing the structure of the pyramid (that is not restored and still covered by gigantic hill), samples of wall paintings and items found during the archeological works. Great view from the top of the pyramid where the Spanish church is located. Good opportunity to get inside the pyramid.

190225774.name: Pyramid
190225774.author: a TripAdvisor user
190225774.reviewBody: This is the place where the Aztec kings were crowned. It was the site of a major battle (more of a massacre actually) during the Spanish conquest. Once you\'ve laid eyes on the immensity of what is left its easy to imagine how grand it was once upon a time. Now its just an odd shaped hill you know has something really cool and important under it, with an ok church on top. The church replaced what was left of the temple atop the pyramid in colonial times.

189870404.name: Beautiful views from the top
189870404.author: a TripAdvisor user
189870404.reviewBody: Though the pyramid is covered for the most part, this site is well worth the visit.  A very charming church  awaits you at the top, which provides some good views of the city below in all directions.  I did not get into the tunnels, but have heard that they are worth it.  \nThe city of Cholula makes a nice package of sites, including this pyramid, the MANY other churches in the area, a typical Mexican market with numerous food stands, and some shops for tourist stuff.

189819766.name: Utterly fantastic
189819766.author: a TripAdvisor user
189819766.reviewBody: The museum is great; the tunnels are fascinating; the English language guide was knowledgeable and helpful. So interesting to learn about the various pre-Hispanic civilizations, legends, and religious practices, and to see what the Spanish did once they took over.

188957724.name: Exceptional experience to visit tunnels
188957724.author: a TripAdvisor user
188957724.reviewBody: We went durning Christmas holidays and although the tunnels were a bit busy, we still had sections to ourselves which allowed you to really feel the experience. We were able to see a nice and clear view of el Popo which was an added bonus. I would highly recommend figuring out how you can get to the actual pyramid part on the side facing church entrance. We didn\'t see it until we had already left the compound and were not allowed back in. I think before you walk up to church you walk around the exterior to pyramid. All in all it was a nice day trip from DF.

179119906.name: Great view!
179119906.author: a TripAdvisor user
179119906.reviewBody: I loved the view from the top of the mountain - while I would love to see Popocatepetl with snow... for that, you will need to wait till December - basically winter time. You cannot than many pictures as you would like, but still to walk to the tower it is a good experience.

179103847.name: Fun and interesting afternoon
179103847.author: a TripAdvisor user
179103847.reviewBody: We\'ve visited the pyramid about 6 times in the last few years while visiting the area with our missions team. For several years we were not allowed in the underground tunnels, but they have opened up again and it is an extra little piece to see how the archeologists worked and found the different levels/eras of the pyramid. We usually get a guide who speaks English and let them tell us all about the pyramid. Wandering the grounds and see the outer excavated areas are neat. There are many drawings and an amphitheater type area. The walk to the top is exhausting, but the views are beautiful. You can see so many of the churches that still remain in Cholula and all the brightly colored buildings. The church at the top is beautiful and I didn\'t realize that if you walk all the way to the front, there is a little tour of the back area with beautiful carvings and pictures as well. The city is a beautiful place for photos, especially the little market area and small shops on the nearby streets. Highly recommended for an afternoon of touristing.

177728751.name: Fascinating archaeological site
177728751.author: a TripAdvisor user
177728751.reviewBody: The tunnels are not that interesting, though there are guides you can pay to take you through and they will spout off most of what you can read online about the site. Walking around the far side and seeing the size and scope of the site is interesting - again do your reading ahead of time.

177728399.name: Amazing
177728399.author: a TripAdvisor user
177728399.reviewBody: First you have to go to the museum, it\'s small but good. Then you walk through a tunnel system through the pyramid. The pyramid outside is not so fantastic but the church on top the pyramid is very beautiful. From there you have a great view over Cholula.

175740589.name: It is worth to visit!
175740589.author: a TripAdvisor user
175740589.reviewBody: If you are in Puebla city I will recommend to visit Cholula. It is about 30 min from there, but If you are in Mexico City then visit Teotihuacan instead. \nI enjoy my visit there It was a lot of fun inside the tunnels my nieces enjoy playing hide a seek, and scaring each other inside.

174747503.name: Cholula
174747503.author: a TripAdvisor user
174747503.reviewBody: You must visit Cholula. The pyramid is the largest (widest, not tallest) in the world. The town is lovely and has 2 important churches.

171087098.name: interesting
171087098.author: a TripAdvisor user
171087098.reviewBody: first you need to visit the very small museum, then to the tunnels which are really interesting, then there are the other excavated part at ground level with a tombstone like rock that when you clap infront of it the sound bounces back at you, then you can walk up to the church on the top of the pyramid where there are amazing views.  Also there are people selling things at the top and usually at good prices too. If you are in Puebla it is well worth the visit.

164212858.name: Excellent tour
164212858.author: a TripAdvisor user
164212858.reviewBody: This a tour of four parts. Firstly a walk around the museum which was pretty uninteresting apart from buying some "bug candy" outside and seeing a scale model of the pyramid. Then it was across the road to go through the tunnels. These quite impressive especially as the archaeologists had to excavate without any real knowledge of the actual structure. Looking up and down along the steep staircases gives you a sense of the enormous size of the place. Then outside to explore the external walls and ruins. Finally out to a small artisans area and a special show of 4 men on a very high pole swinging round attached only by rope tied to their ankles! Good tour.

160521337.name: The tunnel is closed
160521337.author: a TripAdvisor user
160521337.reviewBody: I came here expecting to be able to wander the tunnel that the pyramid is known for, only to find out that it\'s been closed for several years due to a collapse. It was a day trip from Mexico City, but I should have spent it at Taxco instead. The scenery of the volcano is nice, and town was also pretty, but it\'s not much different from most other colonial towns in Mexico. The pyramid itself is nothing much since it\'s not restored. You can\'t even tell it\'s a pyramid. If you intend to come here as a day trip from the DF, go to Taxco instead.

158709578.name: Pyramid of Cholula - worth it from Puebla, probably not from Mexico City
158709578.author: a TripAdvisor user
158709578.reviewBody:
The pyramid in Cholula is the largest archaeological pyramid site in the Americas. It was a pyramid used for worship by the native peoples but when the Spaniards came, disapproving of the worship of what they considered to be false idols, they buried the pyramid and built a church on top. Today you can visit the church, the tunnels in the buried portion of the pyramid, and the ruins at the base of the pyramid. From the top you can also see the twin volcanoes close by. 

Entrance into the tunnels is about $4 USD. 

This was a fun little trip from Puebla and I enjoyed myself, but I'm not sure it would be worth it to visit from Mexico City or another city farther away than Puebla. The church isn't anything special and the tunnels are just that - tunnels. Enjoyable enough but not worth a long journey to see.

157374258.name: worth visiting if your in the area. but dont go out of your way
157374258.author: a TripAdvisor user
157374258.reviewBody: how crazy i went to cholula once and missed the pyramid becuase it looks nothing like the others ive been to. driving by it looks like a big grassy hill with a church on top! the city is a cute little place with a nice zocalo and the pyamid is cool to see. i think others are better so if your deciding choose others.

154665278.name: The main attraction in Cholula
154665278.author: a TripAdvisor user
154665278.reviewBody: It\'s not Teotihuacan, but it\'s a pretty impressive structure right smack in the middle of town.  We spent 2+ hours visiting the pyramid and the church on top of it.  The lower levels include very long excavated tunnels - not for the claustrophobic or for anyone over 6\' tall.  I expected them to be the highlight of the visit but they weren\'t.  More impressive are the outdoor ruins that have been excavated on the west side.  There\'s a lot to see and the signage is in both English and Spanish.  The climb to the top is well worth it for the views of the surrounding area and for the stunning church at the top.  The museum across the street is small but worth a visit.

154539330.name: Quetzacoatl, Boladores de Papantla, and Pulque.
154539330.author: a TripAdvisor user
154539330.reviewBody: This was an amazing experience! It is a must if you find yourself in Puebla. You get to climb parts of the pyramid which is not allowed in most authentic pyramids. Once you are on top of the pyramid, which was turned into a church by the Spanish conquistadors, you get a view of the whole city including the famous volcano Popocatepetl meaning "white smoke". If you are lucky you will also get to see los voladores which is an amazing ritual to the sun. There are also aztec dancers who perform mostly during the weekends. I had the pleasure of meeting them and they welcomed me and told me history of Mexico while they shared homemade Pulque which is an alcoholic beverage derived from the Agave plant. Out of all the beautiful places that I\'ve been to this experience was by far the best because I was given such a great hospitality by the locals that I felt like I lives there my whole life.

153694045.name: Pretty cool historical site in Mexico
153694045.author: a TripAdvisor user
153694045.reviewBody: We hired guide for our tour of Cholula which I strongly recommend.  It included a walk through the tunnels under the remains of the pyramid.  Then outside to the excavated part of the pyramid.   They did build an artificial pyramid on one side of the mountain to better represent what it looked like before it was covered in dirt.  You can also climb the artificial pyramid which was pretty cool.

153226781.name: You don\'t have to go to Egypt
153226781.author: a TripAdvisor user
153226781.reviewBody: First I climbed the pyramid in this tiny town, all the way to the top where rests a beautiful church.  I had thought I was in great shape but I made a lot of breathing stops.  The view was incredible and the active volcano, Popocatepetl was breathtaking.  Then I went to the base and walked through the tunnel that was carved out through the pyramid.  I was the only one walking there and I am 5\'7" and almost had to duck.  It was well lit, cooler than the hot sun outside and I felt like I was back in time.  I emerged to the ruins of many temples and carvings and a sacrificial altar to the rain god, Tlaloc.  The explanatory signs were written in English, Spanish and Nahautl Indian. Lovely.

151577891.name: Really nice!
151577891.author: a TripAdvisor user
151577891.reviewBody:
The church that's above the pyramids is really nice! The church was build buy the Spanish when the conquest Mexico. It was a symbols that the catholic religion and god was above the religion of the local people. 
I went there in a sunny day and the view is wonderful! You can see the volcano how is still in activity and at his right "the sleeping women" how is a mountain how like at a sleeping women.
If you go upstairs you will see on the way people who are selling cooked insects, don't be afraid and try it's really good! 
If it's open how have also to go (whith a guide for explication) downstairs in the tunnels of the pyramid!

149371634.name: Incredible man made marvel, you can see the Mexico\'s history there.
149371634.author: a TripAdvisor user
149371634.reviewBody:
There are several places in Mexico that represents one of its historic stages but this is one of the few of them where you can see the three main periods of the mexican history in the same place: prehispanic, colony and modern.
The largest base pyramid in the world with one of the most beautiful colonial catholic church at the top surrounded by the modern city of Puebla with their high ranked universities, zoo's and beatiful volcanoes makes this atraction unique.
First, you can visit the prehispanic museum, after that, you can get in the tunnels to explore the hearth of the pyramid for $4usd, if you want a guide, it costs only $15usd for all your family.
After that, you should climb the pyramid by the stairs and reach the church, there you can see 360º panoramiv views of the city and if you are lucky, you will see both volcanoes Popo and Izta.  Insight the church, there is a wall with most of the legends of the town printed there in spanish and english.
Finally, once you are down again, there is a park where you can see the show of the Voladores de Papantla, they risk their lives every half hour for your voluntary donation, also you will find a small market with beautiful artcrafts and a lot of mexican food.
If the day was too warm for you, let the small kids play on the dancing fountain and if they caught by the intermitent water sprays, they will be refreshed (don't drink that water).
I encourage you to search more over this place on the internet, you will find amazing facts about this place, one of the most unknow of them is the relative position of this pyramid with the Templo Mayor in Mexico city and the sun orbit during winter solstice, you will be surprised.
If you want to know more details about this place, mark this as useful for you so I will write a more detailed review.

148152835.name: Underwhelmed
148152835.author: a TripAdvisor user
148152835.reviewBody: Compared to other pyramid sites in Mexico, such as Teotihuacan, a visit to this one seems of little value. You can have a guide take you through the (modern) tunnels inside. It is cramped, cold, and they may or may not know what they are talking about. The park like area surrounding is attractive for wandering and climbing. The streets nearby are full of the usual shops selling the usual trinkets. I considered the visit a waste of time.

146588417.name: A magical place to let your imagination run free
146588417.author: a TripAdvisor user
146588417.reviewBody: This pyramid is today hard to notice at first, because vegetation grew all over it, and parts were excavated to build other things, notoriously an imposing asylum in the early 1900. You will first go into the tunnels (not original): kilometres of them exist, and you should hire a guide (not expensive) because if not there is no way of enjoying this mysterious way. Definitely not for claustrophobic people! Afterwards, you will emerge in a field full of ruins of pyramids, where you may let your imagination run free, in order to recreate the imposing scenes that once took place there. Don\'t miss to experience the "bird sound" phenomenon, in the middle of the big stones. End this visit by climbing the rebuilt side of the pyramid... but carefully. The handicraft fair below is scarcely interesting. Climbing to the little church in the top of the pyramid is worthwhile, but mostly for the views it features.

146462249.name: That\'s it?
146462249.author: a TripAdvisor user
146462249.reviewBody:
We left feeling a bit underwhelmed, but to be fair we went without a guide, and it's not particularly well labeled in terms of what you're seeing inside those tunnels. But then the guide would have cost us another 180 pesos, 4 times as much as the admission price... little bit steep, no?

The site museum explains a little bit more -I'd go there first. 

The church is nice. Good views of the volcano. But I really wanted to get that iconic photo of the church in the foreground with the volcano in the background, and that's not here. You have to go somewhere away from the actual site (obviously). But where that is, I still do not know. 

Around the site, old ladies have stands selling everything from chocolate (the ground Mexican chocolate kind) to chapulines (very um... crunchy).

Since it's one of the largest pyramids in the world, I thought we had to make the trip from Mexico City. It would be a shame to come so far and not see it. Figured we'd make it a day trip along with Puebla. But now that we did, we're left kind of wondering whether that day would be better spent seeing something else in Mexico City. Kind of underwhelming, especially if you've been to  Teotihuacan. If you're a student or backpacker who measures time in weeks or months instead of days, definitely go. Otherwise, on a short trip, I'd actually give it a miss.

145978378.name: Well worth a visit
145978378.author: a TripAdvisor user
145978378.reviewBody: We had a guided tour of Cholula which included a walk through the tunnels under the remains of the pyramid.  We also walked to the church on top from where there are stunning views of Popacatepetal volcano.  A must if you are staying in Puebla.

144573072.name: Amazing internal view of the Cholula Pyramid
144573072.author: a TripAdvisor user
144573072.reviewBody: This was an easy 2 hour bus trip from Mexico City, Cholula and Puebla were wonderful!  The little museum alongside the pyramid entrance was pretty good, but the walk through the tunnels  within the pyramid (which looks like a grassy hill) were really incredible, and a bit spooky!\nThe view from the top of the church is well worth the (rigorous) climb up to the top.

136746481.name: The Pyramid with the Catholic Church On Top
136746481.author: a TripAdvisor user
136746481.reviewBody: Cholula, on the outskirts of Puebla, is one of the most interesting small cities in Mexico.  It was a major religious center at the time of the Conquest.  You can read a description of the place in a book (still in print) by Bernal Diaz del Castillo, one of the conquistadores who came with Cort\u00e9s.  The Spanish had most of the native shrines destroyed and built churches at all the temple sites-- they say that there are 365 churches in Cholula.  But the Virgen de los Remedios church is the only one I know that sits on top of one of the great pyramids of Mexico. You can go inside the pyramid itself!  The archaeological site is expansive, with good signage.  I highly recommend using a guide-- he\'ll point out elements that you shouldn\'t miss.  You can walk up to the church, too-- and maybe buy some roasted grasshoppers on the way.

132458541.name: great cultural visit
132458541.author: a TripAdvisor user
132458541.reviewBody: thi is one of the most important attractions on cholula, you must visit it and watch the great view on the top, also there are several culture attractions near it and also restaurants and bars.

130922717.name: Get a Guide
130922717.author: a TripAdvisor user
130922717.reviewBody: I had been through the pyramid a lot of times with locals who were explaining the history to me, but when I went back my family wanted to get a guide, and it turned out that the locals don\'t actually know the history as correctly as they think they do! \nClimb to the top and take a look, it\'s amazing how many churches you can see around Puebla from up there.

130149423.name: artificial mountain
130149423.author: a TripAdvisor user
130149423.reviewBody: Small town Cholula with great pyramid named Tlachihualtepetl (in nahuatl languague means "artificial mountain). On the top of artificial hill is catholic church consecrated to Virgin of Remedies. Great view on Popocatepetl behind the hill and take some pictures. Museum with oveview of local history. Local speciality is "chiapullines" - fried grasshoppers.

129621888.name: Good day trip!
129621888.author: a TripAdvisor user
129621888.reviewBody: The pyramid doesn\'t look that big from the outside but it\'s very interesting and the church on top makes for some great views & photos. Entrance is free and you can enter a museum with artifacts and information about the people who lived here before you visit the pyramids. There is a small plaza right outside with a great view of the pyramid and church, and while I was visiting there was a performance of the flying dancers from Veracruz--very cool! You can also wander to the zocalo of Cholula after the pyramids and visit a small museum or sit outside and people watch!

125980660.name: Magical View - worth the hike
125980660.author: a TripAdvisor user
125980660.reviewBody: This is the largest pyramid although looks like a big hill, since centuries of dirt cover it.  The hike to the top is strenuous and not too easy with the high  altitude. Save this for  a few days into your Mexico trip, after your  body adjusts more to the thinner air.  From the top your view of Popo, La Malinche and all the volcanos, valley and mountains - well worth it.  Magical!

125467724.name: I wish they would have more of the site excavated
125467724.author: a TripAdvisor user
125467724.reviewBody: Apparently you used to be able to enter through a tunnel and see more of the site ... however, according to the staff this has now been closed for about 2 years and there are no plans to reopen.  There is a small museum on site with some artifacts.  A church was constructed at the top of the main pyramid, which due to it\'s existence, most of the pyramid has not been excavated for fear of destabilizing the church.  I think the pyramid was there first, so who cares about the church!!  This is the biggest pyramid in the world (in terms of volume) so I personally would really like to see it excavated.  Very little of the site has actually been uncovered.  There are some small areas around the perimeter which have been excavated, but really nothing very exciting.  This is a site just waiting to be explored.  But until then, there isn\'t a lot to see here.  There were very few people touring while I was there.

125260980.name: A good beginning of ending to your trip
125260980.author: a TripAdvisor user
125260980.reviewBody:
We saw this pyrmid and church atop it near the end of our visit, and therefore had seen bigger pyramid mounrs and more lavish churches.  But knowing Cholula was a major religious site when Cortes arrived and that he made an example of the place, helped us appreciate its unique status.

In the middle of the village, you park at the foot of the pyramid and see a reconstruction of part of the original design.  Most of it is covered in vegetation with outcroppings of adobe and stone.  The climb is steep, with either a ramp or steps.  Two third up there is a flat areas with good prospects for picture and a clot of merchants.  The last third goes to the top, or the leveled area after Cortes demolished the original.  Here stands the church of the remedios, reminiscent of the top of Mount Lykkos in Athens.  A small sanctuary and a smaller chapel, painted yellow.  The plaza encircles it all with many views.  One to the northeast takes in greater Puebla. One to the west takes in Mt. Popocatepetl.  This impressed me because Popo is an active volcano, and through the clouds we could see the cone and the smoke rising from within.  

While not worth a special trip, it is easily added to a visit to Puebla, and worth the stop.  No charge to climb the pyrmid or see the church.  On a clear day the views are excellent, and a few minutes in the church catching one's breath and admiring the chapel is a plus.

123497532.name: Well preserved and intersting
123497532.author: a TripAdvisor user
123497532.reviewBody: Impressive and worth seeing.  You can also get some good photos of it.

123124746.name: Nothing new after visiting Teotihuacan and El Tajin
123124746.author: a TripAdvisor user
123124746.reviewBody: After visiting Teotihuacan pyramid and El Tajin complex, this pyramid does not offer different views. It needs more archeological restauration work and maybe be more interesting for visitors...

115896399.name: Visit the Nearby One-of-a-Kind Church, Sta. Maria de Tonantzintla
115896399.author: a TripAdvisor user
115896399.reviewBody: After visiting the pyramids of Teotihuacan, the great pyramid of Cholula is nothing new. Except, that you can see from the exposed layers of the pyramid how the different ancient builders kept on upgrading the pyramid (hmmm, sounds like us modern people,no?) and that it has a church on top of it.  I didn\'t bother to climb to the church because I figured it could not be as beautiful as the Basilica de Guadalupe or La Catedral, both in Mexico City.\nHowever, the trip to Cholula is made more worthwhile with a side-trip to a nearby church that was built by the indigenous Mexicans in the 1500\'s under the supervision of the Spaniards, the Sta. Maria de Tonantzintla.  It is a one-of-a-kind church, full of elaborately carved  images that  look like the Simpsons (as our very able tour guides from Royal Tours  and Cars pointed  out). Definitely, a must-see attraction!
